Confessionally Reformed Theology

Johannes Hoornbeek (c. 1666) on Christ

[Institutiones Theologicae Ex Optimis Autoribus Concinatae (ex officinâ Francisci Moyardi, 1658)]

Table of Contents:

  • CHAPTER IX. CONCERNING CHRIST
  • I. The Foundation of the Gospel, Religion, and Our Salvation.
  • Things to Be Proven:
  • I. Verily, his Kingdom shall not be of this world, but a spiritual Kingdom, whereby he shall subdue the world unto himself, not by the sword or by might, but by the power of his Word and the efficacy of his Spirit.
  • II. Arguments Concerning the Future Abrogation of the Mosaic Ceremonial Law.
  • III. The Time of the Messiah's Advent.
  • II. Christ Would Not Have Come in the Flesh Had Man Not Sinned.
  • III. Christ Jesus is God-Man.
  • IV. He Was God, the Second Person of the Blessed Trinity.
  • V. Christ is Also Very Man.
  • VI. He Took Upon Him Human Nature from His Mother Mary, by the Working of the Holy Ghost.
  • VII. Thus, the Divine Person of the Son, Having Taken Flesh, Did Unite Unto Himself the Human Nature, So That Both Natures Are Joined in One Person.
  • VIII. Both Natures in Christ Do Retain Their Distinct Properties, and There Is No Transference of Omniscience, Omnipotence, Ubiquity, or the Quality of Being Worshipable Unto the Human Nature.
  • Objection: But the Apostle declareth in Colossians 2:9, 'For in him dwelleth all the fulness of the Godhead bodily.' Therefore, all the divine attributes dwell in him.
  • Second Objection: Yet divine attributes are at times ascribed unto Christ in his humanity. For instance, in Matthew 28:18, 'All power is given unto me in heaven and in earth.'
  • Instance: But it is said that power (δύναμις) is also given unto him. For he forgiveth sins as the Son of man, Matthew 9:6, 'But that ye may know that the Son of man hath power on earth to forgive sins,' and in Revelation 5:12, 'Saying with a loud voice, Worthy is the Lamb that was slain to receive power (δύναμιν), and riches, and wisdom, and strength, and honour, and glory, and blessing.'
  • Second Instance: Yet he is worshiped.
  • Third Instance: It is said that the flesh of Christ giveth life, as in John 6:51, 'I am the living bread which came down from heaven: if any man eat of this bread, he shall live for ever: and the bread that I will give is my flesh, which I will give for the life of the world.'
  • Question of Ubiquity: It is inquired whether, by this union, ubiquity is imparted unto the human nature of Christ, as certain Ubiquitarians of our time do hold, who assert that the communication of these attributes is a consequence of the union, and in this they follow the opinion of Brentius and others, who infer it from Christ's sitting at the right hand of God.
  • Instance: But they may reply that these scriptures speak of his visible presence, not of an invisible presence.
  • Objection: Christ sitteth at the right hand of God, and since God is everywhere, therefore Christ is everywhere according to both his natures.
  • Objection: If the human nature is not present wherever the divine nature is, then the divine nature is not united to the human nature in every place.
  • Question of Omniscience: A second question ariseth between us and the Ubiquitarians: whether omniscience was not truly communicated unto Christ by means of the hypostatic union.
  • Question of Adorability: It is inquired whether the quality of being worshipable is also imparted unto his flesh.
  • Further Inquiry: Here the question is raised: whether Christ, in his capacity as mediator, is to be adored with religious worship, and consequently, whether in his mediatorial office there lieth the fundamental reason (that for which) and the formal reason (that under which) of divine worship; or whether he is to be worshiped only insofar as he is God absolute, together with the Father and the Holy Ghost.
  • IX. From This Union of the Two Natures, There Ariseth Divers Manners of Speaking Concerning Christ, Whether in Reference to His Person or to His Natures, Which Is Called the Communication of Properties.
  • X. The Office of Christ Is in General Twofold, to Be a Mediator, and a Saviour, That Is, Jesus.
  • XI. To Which He Was Anointed by God, or Endued with a Singular Calling and Gifts, That Is, Christ.
  • XII. Christ Jesus is the One and Perfect Mediator.
  • XIII. And He is Mediator According to Both Natures.
  • XIV. The Parts of Christ’s Office Are to Be a Prophet, a Priest, and a King.
  • XV. For His Prophetic Office, Christ Teacheth the Church the Saving Truth of Religion.
  • XVI. But He Did Not Add to the Moral Law with New or More Perfect Precepts.
  • XVII. Christ’s Priestly Office Consisteth in That He Offered Himself to God as a True Expiation for Sins, and Continually Intercedeth for Us Before the Father.
  • XVIII. By True Satisfaction, Christ Expiated Our Sins.
  • XIX. Christ Suffered for Us Both Bodily and Spiritual Pains, Even the Gravest Punishments in His Soul.
  • XX. And Thus He Satisfied the Law with the Fullest Righteousness, Both Active and Passive.
  • XXI. And Thus He Merited Salvation for Us from God.
  • XXII. Christ Performed These Things for His Elect and Those to Be Saved, Only and All, Who Have Lived, or Will Live.
  • XXIII. And for the Same, Christ Continually Intercedeth Before the Father.
  • XXIV. Christ Showeth Himself a King in Gathering, Preserving, and Promoting the Church, That Is, His Spiritual Kingdom.
  • XXV. The State of Christ is Twofold: Humiliation & Exaltation. The Former Beginneth from Christ’s Conception and Endeth in His Death.
  • XXVI. The State of Christ’s Exaltation Beginneth from His Resurrection, and Besides It, Includeth His Ascension and His Session at the Right Hand.

CHAPTER IX. CONCERNING CHRIST

I. The Foundation of the Gospel, Religion, and Our Salvation.

The foundation of the Gospel, of true religion, and of our eternal salvation is none other than Christ Jesus; concerning whom we must now discourse, and first it is meet to know that he is the very Messiah foretold in the sacred Scriptures of the Old Testament.

ZWINGLI. Therefore, our gracious Creator, in his infinite mercy, deigned at last to succor our most desolate cause, sending not an angel, nor a mere man, but his only begotten Son, clothed in our frail flesh, that neither his divine majesty might affright us from approaching him, nor his lowly humility cause us to despair of hope. For inasmuch as he is very God and the Son of God, sent as our mediator and intercessor, he doth uphold our hope: for what is there that he cannot do, or what doth he lack, who is the Almighty God? Yet, being also true man, he doth vouchsafe unto us familiarity, friendship, yea, even kinship and fellowship. For what can he withhold, who is our brother, partaking of our infirmities? Moreover, this wondrous and unparalleled mystery hath been set forth and ordained from the very dawn of human wretchedness.

WAL. The sacred name of the Messiah, in the Hebrew tongue Maschia, doth derive from the root משה, signifying to anoint: and it is equivalent to Christ in the Greek, from χρίω or χρίζω, which meaneth 'I anoint.' Of this divine anointing of the Messiah, the holy Prophet David beareth witness, Psalm 45:7, 'Therefore God, even thy God, hath anointed thee with the oil of gladness above thy companions.' And the Prophet Isaiah, 61:1, 'The Spirit of the Lord Jehovah is upon me, for that Jehovah hath anointed me to proclaim glad tidings unto the meek; he hath sent me': whereby in this latter passage is set forth the manner of his anointing, to wit, by that divine appointment unto his office, and by the Holy Spirit, as the blessed Apostles do expound, Acts 10:38, 'How God anointed Jesus of Nazareth with the Holy Ghost and with power.' And again, Acts 2:36, 'Therefore let all the house of Israel know assuredly, that God hath made that same Jesus, whom ye have crucified, both Lord and Christ.' The name Jesus doth proceed from the Hebrew word signifying 'to save,' not from law, as certain Greeks have mistakenly supposed, albeit the etymology proposed by Avenarius be not altogether astray, which deriveth the word ἰάω or ἰάζω from ישע. Even as Jesus is the same as Joshua, for Joshua the son of Nun is named Jesus in the New Testament, Hebrews 4:8. Here let us observe, by the way, that we are rightly denominated Christians, according to the Scriptures; whereas some are wrongly called Jesuits; for in the work of salvation, Christ admitteth no partners, as it is written, Acts 4:12, 'Neither is there salvation in any other.' Yet in his anointing, he hath fellows, as it is said, Psalm 45:7, 'Above thy fellows.'

Things to Be Proven:

It is incumbent upon us to demonstrate:

  1. That the Messiah is promised in Holy Writ as a King whose dominion is spiritual, not temporal; who shall suffer death, yet rise again, and after his resurrection shall live unto all eternity.
  2. That the ceremonial laws and the Temple worship shall be utterly abolished upon his advent.
  3. That the appointed time of his coming hath long since elapsed.
  4. And that he is indeed Jesus Christ, our blessed Savior; wherefore, no other Messiah is to be looked for.

I. Verily, his Kingdom shall not be of this world, but a spiritual Kingdom, whereby he shall subdue the world unto himself, not by the sword or by might, but by the power of his Word and the efficacy of his Spirit.

This is proven:

  1. Forasmuch as God doth never establish for himself a kingdom that is worldly and outward. For he is the sovereign Lord of all, who raiseth up kings and casteth them down according to his good pleasure, as it is written in Proverbs 8:15, 'By me kings reign, and princes decree justice,' and Daniel 2:21, 'He changeth the times and the seasons: he removeth kings, and setteth up kings.' Moreover, the Messiah is very God, as we have heretofore shown from the Old Testament Scriptures.
  2. All the kingdoms of this earth are subject to decay and corruption: but the Kingdom of the Messiah is promised to be everlasting, never to be overthrown: therefore, etc. The truth of this is self-evident: for the world itself is perishable, as the Psalmist declareth, Psalm 102:26, 'They shall perish, but thou shalt endure.' And the Preacher saith, Ecclesiastes 1:4, 'I have beheld all the works that are wrought under the sun; and lo, all is vanity.' Likewise, Isaiah proclaimeth, Isaiah 40:6, 'All flesh is as grass, and all the glory thereof as the flower of the field: the grass withereth, the flower fadeth: but the word of our God shall abide forever.' The minor premise is established by Psalm 45:6, 'Thy throne, O God, is established from everlasting to everlasting.' And also by Daniel 2:44, 'In the days of those kings shall the God of heaven set up a kingdom which shall never be destroyed: and the kingdom shall not be delivered to another people, but it shall break in pieces and consume all these kingdoms, and it shall stand forever.' Nor is this to be interpreted merely of a protracted period, as the Hebrew term עולם doth sometimes signify, but of an eternity absolute and without end: for it shall never be overthrown, neither shall it be given over to any other people, even as it is written in Daniel 7:14, 'And there was given him dominion, and glory, and a kingdom, that all peoples, nations, and tongues should serve him: his dominion is an everlasting dominion, which shall not pass away, and his kingdom that which shall not be destroyed.'
  3. From the manner and the form of the Messiah's kingdom, which is everywhere described in such wise that it pertaineth not to any earthly dominion. For:
    • His throne is at the right hand of God, as it is written in Psalm 110:1, 'The Lord said unto my Lord, Sit thou at my right hand,' which doth plainly signify a kingdom that is spiritual.
    • His scepter is his word, which shall go forth from Zion, Psalm 110:2, 'The Lord shall send the rod of thy strength out of Zion.' And Isaiah prophesieth, Isaiah 2:3, 'For out of Zion shall go forth the law, and the word of the Lord from Jerusalem. And he shall judge among the nations, and shall rebuke many people.'
    • Moreover, the office of preaching is laid upon him, and that with exceeding meekness, as Isaiah declareth, Isaiah 42:1, 'Behold my servant, whom I uphold; mine elect, in whom my soul delighteth,' etc., 'He shall not cry, nor lift up, nor cause his voice to be heard in the street. A bruised reed shall he not break, and the smoking flax shall he not quench: he shall bring forth judgment unto truth. He shall not fail nor be discouraged, till he have set judgment in the earth: and the isles shall wait for his law.' Likewise, Isaiah 61:1, 'The Spirit of the Lord God is upon me; because the Lord hath anointed me to preach good tidings unto the meek; he hath sent me to bind up the brokenhearted, to proclaim liberty to the captives, and the opening of the prison to them that are bound; to comfort all that mourn.'
    • And this is conjoined with the deepest humility and disdain for worldly glory. As it is written in Psalm 22:6, 'But I am a worm, and no man; a reproach of men, and despised of the people.' And in Zechariah 9:9, 'Rejoice greatly, O daughter of Zion; shout, O daughter of Jerusalem: behold, thy King cometh unto thee: he is just, and having salvation; lowly, and riding upon an ass, and upon a colt the foal of an ass.'
    • Furthermore, that he was to be rejected by the Jews, to die for the sins of the people, and to rise again from the dead. As David saith in Psalm 16:10, 'For thou wilt not leave my soul in hell; neither wilt thou suffer thine Holy One to see corruption.' And in Psalm 22:1, 'My God, my God, why hast thou forsaken me?' And Isaiah, in that most poignant prophecy, Isaiah 53:3, 'He is despised and rejected of men; a man of sorrows, and acquainted with grief: and we hid as it were our faces from him; he was despised, and we esteemed him not. Surely he hath borne our griefs, and carried our sorrows,' etc.

      • Objection: But they deny that chapter Isaiah 53 is to be understood of the Messiah, but rather of the Prophet himself.

      Response: That this is a manifest error is plain from even a cursory examination of that chapter. For commencing from the second verse, the Prophet speaketh consistently in the third person, as of one distinct from himself, saying, 'He shall grow up before him as a tender plant,' etc., 'He was despised, and we esteemed him not,' yet 'Surely he hath borne our griefs,' etc., 'He was wounded for our transgressions, he was bruised for our iniquities,' etc., 'All we like sheep have gone astray; we have turned every one to his own way; and the Lord hath laid on him the iniquity of us all.' Moreover, there are sundry particulars therein which cannot by any means be applied to the Prophet.

      Objection: But it is said that he speaketh of the people of Israel.

      Response: This likewise is erroneous; for he doth clearly set apart the people of Israel from him of whom he speaketh, declaring, 'He hath borne our griefs, and carried our sorrows,' 'He was wounded for our transgressions, he was bruised for our iniquities: the chastisement of our peace was upon him; and with his stripes we are healed,' etc., 'All we like sheep have gone astray.' And in verse 8, 'He was taken from prison and from judgment: and who shall declare his generation? for he was cut off out of the land of the living: for the transgression of my people was he stricken.' And in verse 11, 'He shall see of the travail of his soul, and shall be satisfied: by his knowledge shall my righteous servant justify many; for he shall bear their iniquities.' And so throughout the chapter.

  4. From the blessed fruits of his kingdom and priesthood; such as:
    • To bear the punishment due to the sins of the entire people, as it is written in Isaiah 53:6, 'And the Lord hath laid on him the iniquity of us all.'
    • To justify a multitude by his knowledge, verse 11, 'By his knowledge shall my righteous servant justify many; for he shall bear their iniquities.'
    • To pour out his soul even unto death, and to intercede for those who slew him, verse 12, 'He was numbered with the transgressors; and he bare the sin of many, and made intercession for the transgressors.'
    • Also, in Daniel 9:24, 'Seventy weeks are determined upon thy people and upon thy holy city, to finish the transgression, and to make an end of sins, and to make reconciliation for iniquity, and to bring in everlasting righteousness, and to seal up the vision and prophecy, and to anoint the most Holy.' All these declarations do manifestly prove that the kingdom here foretold is a kingdom spiritual, not earthly and outward.

II. Arguments Concerning the Future Abrogation of the Mosaic Ceremonial Law.

The reasons which demonstrate the future abolition of the ceremonial law given unto Moses may be summarized under these heads:

  1. For that a new covenant is explicitly promised, whereby the old covenant is to be done away; and this new covenant shall not be like unto that which God established with the fathers in the wilderness. As it is written in Jeremiah 31:31, 'Behold, the days come, saith the Lord, when I will make a new covenant with the house of Israel, and with the house of Judah: not according to the covenant that I made with their fathers in the day that I took them by the hand to bring them out of the land of Egypt.'
  2. For that both the priesthood and the sacrifices were appointed to be altered. Concerning the priesthood, it is written in Psalm 110:4, 'The Lord hath sworn, and will not repent, Thou art a priest for ever after the order of Melchizedek.' And touching the sacrifices, Psalm 40:6, 'Sacrifice and offering thou didst not desire; mine ears hast thou opened: burnt offering and sin offering hast thou not required. Then said I, Lo, I come: in the volume of the book it is written of me, I delight to do thy will, O my God: yea, thy law is within my heart.' And in Malachi 1:11, 'For from the rising of the sun even unto the going down of the same my name shall be great among the Gentiles; and in every place incense shall be offered unto my name, and a pure offering: for my name shall be great among the heathen, saith the Lord of hosts,' whereas under the law, sacrifices were to be presented only in the Temple or the Tabernacle. Furthermore, the Messiah was to offer himself as a sacrifice, as Isaiah prophesieth, Isaiah 53:10, 'Yet it pleased the Lord to bruise him; he hath put him to grief: when thou shalt make his soul an offering for sin, he shall see his seed, he shall prolong his days, and the pleasure of the Lord shall prosper in his hand.' And verse 12, 'Therefore will I divide him a portion with the great, and he shall divide the spoil with the strong; because he hath poured out his soul unto death: and he was numbered with the transgressors; and he bare the sin of many, and made intercession for the transgressors.'
  3. For that the lawgiver was to be changed, as it is foretold in Genesis 49:10, 'The sceptre shall not depart from Judah, nor a lawgiver from between his feet, until Shiloh come; and unto him shall the gathering of the people be.' Hence, the law itself is not to remain unaltered, as the Apostle exhorteth in Romans 13:1, 'Let every soul be subject unto the higher powers,' thereby indicating that we are not bound to the Mosaic law in all its particulars.
  4. Moreover, it is declared that the offerings and sacrifices shall be brought to an end. In Daniel 9:27, 'And he shall confirm the covenant with many for one week: and in the midst of the week he shall cause the sacrifice and the oblation to cease, and for the overspreading of abominations he shall make it desolate, even until the consummation, and that determined shall be poured upon the desolate.' Likewise, in Jeremiah 3:15, 'And I will give you pastors according to mine heart, which shall feed you with knowledge and understanding. And it shall come to pass, when ye be multiplied and increased in the land, in those days, saith the Lord, they shall say no more, The ark of the covenant of the Lord: neither shall it come to mind: neither shall they remember it; neither shall they visit it; neither shall that be done any more.'

Objection: Yet it is objected that this law is frequently declared to be everlasting.

Response: The Hebrew term לעולם doth oftentimes signify a duration that is prolonged and continuous, derived from 'hidden,' akin to the Latin words perpetuum, perenne, juge, and the like. For instance, in Exodus 21:6, it is said, 'Then he shall serve him for ever,' which is to say, for the term of his life, or until the year of Jubilee. And in Jeremiah 25:11, 'And this whole land shall be a desolation, and an astonishment; and these nations shall serve the king of Babylon seventy years,' followed by verse 12, 'And it shall come to pass, when seventy years are accomplished, that I will punish the king of Babylon, and that nation, saith the Lord, for their iniquity, and the land of the Chaldeans, and will make it perpetual desolations.' Moreover, it is manifest that the sacrifices, together with the feasts and ceremonies thereto annexed, as well as numerous civil statutes, did cease during the time of the Babylonian captivity; and likewise, since the overthrow of the Temple and the city even unto this present day, the Jews themselves, though loath to admit it, do witness the same.

III. The Time of the Messiah's Advent.

It now remaineth for us to observe that the time appointed in the Old Testament for the advent of the Messiah hath long since passed, even many hundreds of years ago; wherefore, the Jews, in rejecting the true Messiah, do but vainly look for another.

I. The first scripture to this effect is that renowned and familiar prophecy of Jacob, Genesis 49:10, 'The sceptre shall not depart from Judah, nor a lawgiver from between his feet, until Shiloh come; and unto him shall the obedience of the peoples be.' The Hebrew word שבט doth primarily denote a rod or a branch, and by a figure of speech is employed to signify a sceptre: moreover, in the sacred writings, it is frequently used to represent a tribe, for from the single stock of Jacob sprang forth divers tribes, even as branches from a single tree; in like manner as the Dutch word stamme signifieth: wherefore Tremellius and Junius, in their translation, render it, 'The tribe shall not depart from Judah.' Yet it is commonly understood as 'sceptre,' that is, dominion or governance. Even so, the Chaldean Paraphrase hath it: 'The prince shall not be removed from the house of Judah, nor the scribe from among his descendants, until the Messiah shall come, unto whom the kingdom belongeth, and whom the nations shall obey.' The phrase 'lawgiver from between his feet' is a metaphor drawn from the custom of fathers, who place their sons between their feet or upon their knees, and there nurture them. As for 'Shiloh,' some interpret it as 'his son,' others as 'sent,' others as 'his peace,' deriving it from schaljab, which meaneth to be at peace, or from schil, son, or from schilah, the afterbirth: nevertheless, all do agree that by this name the Messiah is intended.

I pass over here the controversies among Christian divines regarding the precise timing and fulfillment of this prophecy, for some do opine that the sceptre had already departed from Judah in the days of the Maccabees, albeit they maintain that these were of the tribe of Judah through their mother's lineage, for the preservation of the prophecy's meaning. Others hold that the Sanhedrin endured until the era of Herod, by whom it was abolished, as Josephus recordeth in his Antiquities of the Jews, book 15, chapter 11. Yet others, such as Casaubon and Scaliger, do suppose that the Sanhedrin consisted more of priests than of the tribe of Judah. Hence, by 'sceptre,' they interpret the supremacy or privilege of that tribe, which alone retained its name and honour, together with its civil governance, whilst the other tribes were mingled or absorbed into it, and as it were concealed. Therefore, Junius and Tremellius render it 'tribe,' as the term is oft used in Holy Writ. And in this view, there is no difficulty; for this tribe alone was to remain whole and maintain its authority until the Messiah's advent. Thus, the Messiah was to come ere its dissolution, not ere the dissolution of the other tribes. Whichever interpretation be adopted, the argument standeth sure and unassailable against the Jews, to wit: The sceptre, or the tribe of Judah, from whence the Messiah was to spring, did continue: and the Messiah was to appear whilst that tribe yet stood, with its laws and governance. But now, that tribe, with all its distinction and rule, hath perished, and there hath been a confounding of all the tribes these sixteen hundred years past. Therefore, the Messiah must have come already. Which doth accord with the prophecy in Isaiah 11:1, 'And there shall come forth a rod out of the stem of Jesse, and a Branch shall grow out of his roots: and the Spirit of the Lord shall rest upon him,' etc. But the lineage of Jesse is now utterly extinct and unknown; therefore, the Messiah must have come.

Objection: The Jews do raise an objection, asserting that the term schebet ought to be taken in the sense of chastisement.

Response: Such an interpretation is not fitting for this passage. I. For chastisement was a thing common to all the tribes, whereas here the prophecy concerneth a particular privilege belonging to the tribe of Judah. II. Moreover, the word 'lawgiver' which followeth doth refute this notion, for it accordeth not with a rod of correction, but rather with authority or dominion. III. Furthermore, it is a falsehood to claim that all chastisement shall cease in the days of the Messiah, since it is written in Isaiah 53:10, 'Yet it pleased the Lord to bruise him; he hath put him to grief,' and in Daniel 9:27, that the Messiah shall be cut off. And throughout the Scriptures, it is testified that the faithful under the Messiah's reign shall not be exempt from affliction. As it is said in Psalm 72:2, 'He shall judge thy people with righteousness, and thy poor with judgment.' And in Psalm 89:27, 'Also I will make him my firstborn, higher than the kings of the earth. His seed also will I make to endure for ever, and his throne as the days of heaven. If his children forsake my law, and walk not in my judgments; if they break my statutes, and keep not my commandments; then will I visit their transgression with the rod, and their iniquity with stripes. Nevertheless my lovingkindness will I not utterly take from him, nor suffer my faithfulness to fail.'

Objection: The Jews further object, alleging that the governance of those tribes doth yet persist in some region beyond the Caspian mountains, as is recounted in the travels of Benjamin of Tudela.

Response: This is naught but a fable of the Jews, contrary to the testimony of all geographers and historians, both ancient and contemporary, and contrary also to the universal observation of all who have journeyed in those parts.

II. Second Passage: Daniel 9:24-26.

The second scripture is that of Daniel 9:24, 'Seventy weeks are determined upon thy people and upon thy holy city, to finish the transgression, and to make an end of sins, and to make reconciliation for iniquity, and to bring in everlasting righteousness, and to seal up the vision and prophecy, and to anoint the most Holy.' Verse 25, 'Know therefore and understand, that from the going forth of the commandment to restore and to build Jerusalem unto the Messiah the Prince shall be seven weeks, and threescore and two weeks: the street shall be built again, and the wall, even in troublous times.' Verse 26, 'And after threescore and two weeks shall the Messiah be cut off, but not for himself: and the people of the prince that shall come shall destroy the city and the sanctuary; and the end thereof shall be with a flood, and unto the end of the war desolations are determined.'

I shall not here engage in the controversy that existeth among Christian expositors concerning this prophecy; to wit, whether these seventy weeks commence from the first decree of Cyrus, or from that of Artaxerxes Longimanus, when Ezra in chapter 7 and Nehemiah in chapter 2 did return unto Jerusalem; and whether they conclude with the death of Christ or with the destruction of Jerusalem, as Polanus, Junius, Scaliger, and others do maintain, contrary to another commonly accepted interpretation. For it is plainly stated, 'Seventy weeks are determined upon thy people and upon thy holy city,' etc. And this most grievous desolation brought by war, of which our Lord speaketh in Matthew 24:15 and Mark 13:14, 'When ye therefore shall see the abomination of desolation, spoken of by Daniel the prophet, standing in the holy place,' and Luke 21:20, 'And when ye shall see Jerusalem compassed with armies, then know that the desolation thereof is at hand.' Therefore, passing over these matters, we affirm that, by the agreement of all interpreters, the seventy weeks represent four hundred and ninety years from the issuance of that decree; which period doth end either with the death of Christ or with the overthrow of the city. But in that appointed time, the Messiah was to appear and to accomplish all that is here foretold. Hence, it doth necessarily follow that he hath come already, even sixteen hundred years past, and so forth. We shall not here delve into the precise calculations of times.

III. Third Evidence: Prophecies Fulfilled.

Thirdly, from those scriptures wherein it is foretold that certain events shall accompany the advent of the Messiah, which events the entire world now beholdeth as accomplished. To wit:

  1. The Calling of the Gentiles: The vocation of the Gentiles, following the Messiah's coming, unto the fellowship of God's Church and unto conversion to the God of Israel: concerning which it is prophesied in Genesis 9:27, 'God shall enlarge Japheth, and he shall dwell in the tents of Shem;' also in Genesis 49:10, 'unto him shall the gathering of the peoples be;' likewise in Deuteronomy 32:21, 'I will provoke them to jealousy with those which are not a people; I will provoke them to anger with a foolish nation;' and in Jeremiah 3:17, 'At that time they shall call Jerusalem the throne of the Lord; and all the nations shall be gathered unto it, to the name of the Lord, to Jerusalem.' That this was to occur after the Messiah's arrival is evidenced by numerous passages. In Genesis 49:10, 'The sceptre shall not depart from Judah, nor a lawgiver from between his feet, until Shiloh come; and unto him shall the obedience of the peoples be.' In Psalm 72:11, 'Yea, all kings shall fall down before him: all nations shall serve him.' In Isaiah 11:10, 'And in that day there shall be a root of Jesse, which shall stand for an ensign of the peoples; to him shall the Gentiles seek: and his rest shall be glorious.' In Isaiah 49:6, 'And he said, It is a light thing that thou shouldest be my servant to raise up the tribes of Jacob, and to restore the preserved of Israel: I will also give thee for a light to the Gentiles, that thou mayest be my salvation unto the end of the earth.' And in Isaiah 60:3, 'And the Gentiles shall come to thy light, and kings to the brightness of thy rising.' Also in Haggai 2:6-7, 'For thus saith the Lord of hosts; Yet once, it is a little while, and I will shake the heavens, and the earth, and the sea, and the dry land; and I will shake all nations, and the desire of all nations shall come: and I will fill this house with glory, saith the Lord of hosts.' And indeed, the turning of the Gentiles unto the God of Israel is manifest throughout the earth, and so forth.
  2. The Abolition of Sacrifices and Ceremonies: The utter abrogation of the sacrifices, ceremonies, and the whole Mosaic law, together with the dissolution of the Jewish commonwealth, which came to pass fifteen hundred years since, and that without any prospect of their restoration, as hath been heretofore demonstrated.
  3. The Abolition of Gentile Idolatry: The eradication of the idolatry practiced by the heathen, which was foretold to occur through the advent of the Messiah, as in Isaiah chapter 2, where, beginning from verse 2, he prophesieth of the Messiah's coming—a truth acknowledged even by the Jews themselves—and then in verse 18, 'And the idols he shall utterly abolish.' And in verse 20, 'In that day a man shall cast away his idols of silver, and his idols of gold, which they made each one for himself to worship, to the moles and to the bats.' Similarly, in Micah chapter 5, after prophesying of Christ from verse 2 onward, he declareth in verse 12, 'And I will cut off witchcrafts out of thine hand; and thou shalt have no more soothsayers: thy graven images also will I cut off, and thy standing images out of the midst of thee; and thou shalt no more worship the work of thine hands.' Likewise, in Zechariah 13:1, 'In that day there shall be a fountain opened to the house of David and to the inhabitants of Jerusalem for sin and for uncleanness.' And in verse 2, 'And it shall come to pass in that day, saith the Lord of hosts, that I will cut off the names of the idols out of the land, and they shall no more be remembered: and also I will cause the prophets and the unclean spirit to pass out of the land.'

    4. Objection: Yet it is urged that sundry things have not yet come to pass: such as that which is foretold in Isaiah 2:2, 'And it shall come to pass in the last days, that the mountain of the Lord's house shall be established in the top of the mountains, and shall be exalted above the hills; and all nations shall flow unto it.' And in another place, 'Every valley shall be exalted, and every mountain and hill shall be made low: and the crooked shall be made straight, and the rough places plain.' Also, that the wild beasts shall live in harmony with the tame. Moreover, that the temple described in the final chapters of Ezekiel shall be rebuilt. Likewise, in Zechariah 12:10, 'And I will pour upon the house of David, and upon the inhabitants of Jerusalem, the spirit of grace and of supplications: and they shall look upon me whom they have pierced, and they shall mourn for him, as one mourneth for his only son.'

    Response: These prophecies must of necessity be interpreted in an allegorical sense, not according to the vain imaginations and foolish glosses of the Jews, as though God intended to alter the natural order of creation. The passage in Haggai 2:8-9 is often cited in this context, to wit, that the Messiah was to come whilst the second temple yet stood, for it is expressly stated, 'The silver is mine, and the gold is mine, saith the Lord of hosts. The glory of this latter house shall be greater than of the former, saith the Lord of hosts: and in this place will I give peace, saith the Lord of hosts.' For the Lord himself was to enter into his temple.

IV. Fourthly: Jesus Christ is the True Messiah.

Fourthly, it followeth that Jesus Christ, the son of Mary, is indeed that true Messiah, promised of old unto the patriarchs and revealed unto us. The proofs hereof are twofold: those which are internal, within us, and those which are external, outside us.

Internal Arguments: The internal evidences are those divine blessings which, through the coming of the Messiah, are vouchsafed unto every believer and unto the whole Church; blessings whereof they who put their trust in him do effectually partake and know within themselves: such as the forgiveness of sins, the peace of conscience, regeneration and sanctification, the witness of the Spirit that through him we are the sons of God, and by the same Spirit we cry, 'Abba, Father'; moreover, the invincible hope of obtaining the inheritance through him. All these things, being promised through the Messiah and his kingdom, as hath been shown above, it doth necessarily follow that he is that true and promised Messiah and mediator, by whom these graces are bestowed. Unto this argument do Christ himself and his Apostles at times direct the faithful. As it is written, 'He that loveth me shall be loved of my Father, and I will love him, and will manifest myself to him,' John 14:21. And again, 'Even the Spirit of truth; whom the world cannot receive, because it seeth him not, neither knoweth him: but ye know him; for he dwelleth with you, and shall be in you,' John 14:17. Also, 'But when the Comforter is come, whom I will send unto you from the Father, even the Spirit of truth, which proceedeth from the Father, he shall testify of me,' John 15:26. And further, 'He shall glorify me: for he shall receive of mine, and shall shew it unto you,' John 16:14. Likewise, the Apostle saith, 'Ye are our epistle written in our hearts, known and read of all men: forasmuch as ye are manifestly declared to be the epistle of Christ ministered by us, written not with ink, but with the Spirit of the living God; not in tables of stone, but in fleshy tables of the heart,' 2 Corinthians 3:2-3. And again, 'Examine yourselves, whether ye be in the faith; prove your own selves. Know ye not your own selves, how that Jesus Christ is in you, except ye be reprobates?' 2 Corinthians 13:5. That is, unless ye be void of all discernment. So also to the Galatians, 'O foolish Galatians, who hath bewitched you, that ye should not obey the truth, before whose eyes Jesus Christ hath been evidently set forth, crucified among you? This only would I learn of you, Received ye the Spirit by the works of the law, or by the hearing of faith?' Galatians 3:1-2.

Objection: But this line of reasoning is known and persuasive only to the faithful, not to unbelievers and the Jews.

Response: I grant it; yet even so, the unbelievers do behold the fruits of this truth in those who are truly faithful, and they themselves do experience the power of the divine threatenings against such as set themselves against Christ, both in their own persons and in others, and that in every place and age.

External Arguments: Therefore, let us proceed to the external arguments:

  1. Fulfillment of Prophecies: If all things concerning the Messiah, as foretold in the Scriptures, have been fulfilled in Jesus Christ, then he is the true Messiah. The antecedent is true; therefore, the consequent must also be true. The particulars of his person, his office, the time of his coming, and the benefits he bestoweth, have been pointed out by us from the Old Testament. That these have their perfect fulfillment in Christ is demonstrated throughout the New Testament. For the place of his birth, Bethlehem; his virgin mother; his flight into Egypt; his life, death, and resurrection—all these were accomplished precisely as prophesied. Wherefore, when John the Baptist sent unto him, inquiring, 'Art thou he that should come, or do we look for another?' Jesus answered, 'Go and shew John again those things which ye do hear and see: the blind receive their sight, and the lame walk, the lepers are cleansed, and the deaf hear, the dead are raised up, and the poor have the gospel preached to them,' Matthew 11:4-5.
  2. Marks of Divinity: Indeed, all the characteristics by which the divinity of the New Testament is established do likewise confirm this truth.
  3. Calling of the Gentiles: The effectual calling of the Gentiles, in accordance with the ancient prophecies, unto the communion of the Church, and the abolition of pagan idolatry following the advent of Christ through the preaching of his Apostles, do most clearly attest the same.
  4. Predictions of Destruction: The prophecies uttered by Christ and his Apostles concerning the destruction of the Jewish nation and the city of Jerusalem, without any hope of restoration, as a punishment for their rejection of him—for they rejected Christ, and he said, 'Behold, your house is left unto you desolate,' Matthew 23:38—these things, foretold by Christ long before, and declared unto them with solemn warnings, and at last confirmed by the event itself, do also plainly convict them that he is the true Messiah, whom they have spurned, and for whose rejection they suffer punishment. For lo, these fifteen hundred years and more, they abide in their exile and wretchedness.

    5. Objection: But it is said that this befell them because of the sins of their forefathers.

    Response: What sins? Idolatry? Yet they have not committed idolatry since the time of the Babylonian captivity, for which they were held in bondage but seventy years; whereas now they have been in this state for over fifteen hundred years. And during their captivity, they had their prophets, but in their present exile, they have no such thing. Therefore, a far more heinous sin must they have committed than idolatry: which can be none other than their obstinate rejection of the Messiah himself, when they cried, 'His blood be on us, and on our children.' Behold Daniel 9:26, 'And after threescore and two weeks shall Messiah be cut off, but not for himself: and the people of the prince that shall come shall destroy the city and the sanctuary; and the end thereof shall be with a flood, and unto the end of the war desolations are determined.' And verse 27, 'And he shall confirm the covenant with many for one week: and in the midst of the week he shall cause the sacrifice and the oblation to cease, and for the overspreading of abominations he shall make it desolate, even until the consummation, and that determined shall be poured upon the desolate.'

  5. Miracles: The miracles wrought by the Apostles and their successors in the name of Christ after his ascension, which continued for nigh two hundred years, as all ancient histories bear witness. Of these miracles, even the Jews themselves make mention, as may be seen in Josephus, and their own Rabbis do confess them; albeit they attribute them to some fabulous tale of discovering the tetragrammaton. Which fables are skillfully refuted by Ludovicus Vives.
  6. Efficacy of Doctrine: The power of his doctrine, which, without the use of arms, but solely by the efficacy of the Spirit, subdued the world and Satan. For Mohammed achieved his ends through warfare, sensual pleasures, and plunder: but in the Christian faith, there is nothing of the sort; rather, they accomplished it armed only with patience, humility, and the potency of their teaching, against all the force and tyranny of man.
  7. Excellence vs. Folly: Finally, on the one side, the surpassing excellence of Christ's doctrine and its divine sublimity, which the most righteous, holy, and wise men in the world have revered from the time it was made known unto them: and on the other side, the stupefaction and folly of the Jews' hearts in devising and embracing the most absurd fables, such as are found in the Talmud and other writings and traditions of theirs—fables, I say, that are mere old wives' tales, as are detailed by Buxtorf in his work on the Synagogue of the Jews, by Ludovicus Vives in his book on the Truth of Christian Doctrine, and by others—these things are a sure and unconquerable sign that they have been given over by God to a reprobate mind, devoid of all sound judgment, even as the Lord doth threaten in Deuteronomy 28:28, 'The Lord shall smite thee with madness, and blindness, and astonishment of heart: and thou shalt grope at noonday, as the blind gropeth in darkness.'

II. Christ Would Not Have Come in the Flesh Had Man Not Sinned.

WAL: The inquiry is raised: Would Christ have taken upon him our flesh had man not sinned nor fallen?

Response: This matter is much debated among the Schoolmen. We deem it not necessary to engage in anxious disputation thereon; yet, inasmuch as Osiander, in the century past, did press this point among our brethren, asserting moreover that the righteousness of his divinity is imputed unto us for righteousness, we shall briefly set forth our judgment:

  1. In the Holy Scriptures, no other reason is given for Christ's incarnation than that he might redeem us; hence, we ought not to seek any higher or different cause. As the Apostle declareth, Galatians 4:4-5, 'But when the fulness of the time was come, God sent forth his Son, made of a woman, made under the law, to redeem them that were under the law, that we might receive the adoption of sons.' And in Hebrews 2:14, 'Forasmuch then as the children are partakers of flesh and blood, he also himself likewise took part of the same; that through death he might destroy him that had the power of death, that is, the devil.' And thus throughout the Scriptures, as in 2 Corinthians 5:21, 'For he hath made him to be sin for us, who knew no sin; that we might be made the righteousness of God in him.'
  2. Since Christ is said to have been made like unto us in all things, sin excepted, as it is written in Hebrews 2:17, 'Wherefore in all things it behoved him to be made like unto his brethren,' and Hebrews 4:15, 'For we have not an high priest which cannot be touched with the feeling of our infirmities; but was in all points tempted like as we are, yet without sin,' and Romans 8:3, 'For what the law could not do, in that it was weak through the flesh, God sending his own Son in the likeness of sinful flesh, and for sin, condemned sin in the flesh,' therefore is he called the second Adam, 1 Corinthians 15:45, 'And so it is written, The first man Adam was made a living soul; the last Adam was made a quickening spirit.' But if the human nature had been ordained for him prior to man's fall, then we should have been created in his image, and he would needs be termed the first Adam.

III. Christ Jesus is God-Man.

MACCO: That in Christ there are two natures, distinct and unconfounded, is most plainly taught throughout the Scriptures, as in Romans 1:2-3, 'Which he had promised afore by his prophets in the holy scriptures, concerning his Son Jesus Christ our Lord, which was made of the seed of David according to the flesh;' and Romans 9:5, 'Whose are the fathers, and of whom as concerning the flesh Christ came, who is over all, God blessed for ever. Amen.' Now, the reasons why it was requisite that Christ should be both God and man in one person are of the utmost gravity. For:

  • That he might be man, it was demanded by:
    1. The righteousness of God; for since man had sinned, it was meet that he who should make satisfaction unto God for man's sin should himself be man.
    2. The manner of satisfaction on our behalf, which could be none other than the perfect obedience unto the law and the enduring of the penalty of death, which the law had pronounced against us.
  • That he might be God, two reasons were necessary:
    1. The exceeding greatness of the evil under which the human race groaned, an evil which no mere creature could remove; and this evil consisteth in the heinousness of sin, the infinite and unbearable weight of God's wrath, the dominion of death, and the tyranny of the devil. But to atone for sin, to pacify the wrath of God, to overthrow the reign of death, and to break the power of the devil, none can accomplish save God alone.
    2. The surpassing greatness of the good which was to be conferred upon us, and effectually secured and preserved; which good none can bestow and maintain but God, who is the supreme good.

Thus, he must needs be man, that he might be subject unto the law and suffer death; and he must needs be God, that he might impart unto both the requisite efficacy and merit.

IV. He Was God, the Second Person of the Blessed Trinity.

WAL: It is well known that the Socinians, following in the footsteps of the ancient Ebionites and of Cerinthus (against whom, as the fathers bear witness, the Evangelist John did pen his Gospel), do deny that Christ had any existence prior to his birth of the virgin Mary. The Arians, on the other hand, do grant that he possessed a certain subsisting nature from the creation of the world, yet they affirm that this nature was the first among all creatures and brought forth in time. But that Christ is very God is unassailably demonstrated by the ensuing arguments:

First Argument: For that he is throughout the Scriptures called God, and all the titles which are proper unto the divine majesty are ascribed unto him; notwithstanding that it is written in Isaiah 42:8, 'I am the Lord: that is my name: and my glory will I not give to another, neither my praise to graven images.'

Objection: But the Socinians object, saying that even Moses is called the God of Aaron in Exodus 4:16, and the judges are termed gods in Psalm 82:6, and angels are called Elohim in Psalm 8:5.

Response: It is true that they are occasionally denominated gods, yet this is solely in respect of their office and a certain resemblance unto God in the discharge of their duties, and with such qualifications as make it abundantly clear that they are not true and eternal gods. For instance, in Exodus 4:16, it is said unto Moses, 'And thou shalt be to him instead of God,' that is, thou shalt act in the stead of God. And in Psalm 82:6, 'I have said, Ye are gods; and all of you are children of the most High. But ye shall die like men, and fall like one of the princes.' Angels, likewise, are sometimes styled Elohim, but in other places they are called the servants of God. And the angel in Revelation 19:10 declareth himself to be a fellow servant with John, and biddeth him worship not himself, but God. Whereas Christ is called God in an absolute sense, and in a manner that pertaineth unto his very being, as in Acts 20:28, 'Take heed therefore unto yourselves, and to all the flock, over the which the Holy Ghost hath made you overseers, to feed the church of God, which he hath purchased with his own blood.' And in 1 Timothy 3:16, 'And without controversy great is the mystery of godliness: God was manifest in the flesh, justified in the Spirit, seen of angels, preached unto the Gentiles, believed on in the world, received up into glory.' Furthermore, he is named Jehovah, as may be seen by comparing the Old Testament with the New. For in Jeremiah 23:6, he is called 'The Lord our righteousness,' and in Isaiah 40:3, 'Prepare ye the way of the Lord.' Thirdly, he is designated God with such titles as can befit no creature: as 'the Lord of glory,' 1 Corinthians 2:8; 'the Lord of hosts,' Isaiah 6 compared with John 12:41; 'God and eternal life,' 1 John 5:20; 'Alpha and Omega, the beginning and the ending, saith the Lord, which is, and which was, and which is to come, the Almighty,' Revelation 1:8; 'the Highest,' Luke 1:76, 'And thou, child, shalt be called the prophet of the Highest: for thou shalt go before the face of the Lord to prepare his ways;' 'one Lord,' 1 Corinthians 8:6; 'the great God and our Saviour Jesus Christ,' Titus 2:13; 'My Lord and my God,' as Thomas confessed, John 20:28; 'KING OF KINGS, AND LORD OF LORDS,' Revelation 19:16, which titles appertain unto God alone, as in 1 Timothy 6:15, 'Which in his times he shall shew, who is the blessed and only Potentate, the King of kings, and Lord of lords.' And many such like passages are to be found throughout the Scriptures, which can be understood of none other than the one true God.

Second Argument: The second class of arguments, whereby the true deity of Christ is unanswerably established, is derived from those attributes which are purely divine and are ascribed unto him in the sacred Scriptures. Such attributes include:

  • His eternity.
  • His omnipotence, as in John 10:28-30, 'And I give unto them eternal life; and they shall never perish, neither shall any man pluck them out of my hand. My Father, which gave them me, is greater than all; and no man is able to pluck them out of my Father's hand. I and my Father are one.' Likewise, in Philippians 3:21, there is attributed unto him that power whereby 'he is able even to subdue all things unto himself.'
  • His omniscience, as Peter confesseth in John 21:17, 'Lord, thou knowest all things; thou knowest that I love thee.'
  • His searching of hearts, Revelation 2:23, 'And I will kill her children with death; and all the churches shall know that I am he which searcheth the reins and hearts: and I will give unto every one of you according to your works.' And in John 2:25, 'And needed not that any should testify of man: for he knew what was in man.'
  • So also, his infinity and omnipresence are affirmed. Matthew 18:20, 'For where two or three are gathered together in my name, there am I in the midst of them.' And Matthew 28:20, 'Lo, I am with you alway, even unto the end of the world.' In Revelation 2:1, he is said to walk in the midst of the seven golden candlesticks, that is, the churches, and to observe and judge their deeds. Yet God claimeth this prerogative unto himself alone, that none can hide from his presence nor escape from his hand, as it is written in Psalm 139:7-10, 'Whither shall I go from thy spirit? or whither shall I flee from thy presence? If I ascend up into heaven, thou art there: if I make my bed in hell, behold, thou art there. If I take the wings of the morning, and dwell in the uttermost parts of the sea; even there shall thy hand lead me, and thy right hand shall hold me.' And in Isaiah 66:1, 'Thus saith the Lord, The heaven is my throne, and the earth is my footstool.' And not only in the Old Testament, but also in the New, this attribute is ascribed solely unto God: namely, the searching of hearts. As in Romans 8:27, 'And he that searcheth the hearts knoweth what is the mind of the Spirit,' and in 1 Thessalonians 2:4, the Apostle saith, 'But as we were allowed of God to be put in trust with the gospel, even so we speak; not as pleasing men, but God, which trieth our hearts.'

Third Argument: The third sort of arguments is drawn from those works which are peculiar unto God, and which are manifestly ascribed unto the Son. Such is:

  • The creation of all things, as in John 1:3, 'All things were made by him; and without him was not any thing made that was made.' Likewise, Colossians 1:16, 'For by him were all things created, that are in heaven, and that are in earth, visible and invisible, whether they be thrones, or dominions, or principalities, or powers: all things were created by him, and for him.' And Hebrews 1:2, 'By whom also he made the worlds.' That the Son is the creator, as the principal agent, is evident from Hebrews 1:10, 'And, Thou, Lord, in the beginning hast laid the foundation of the earth; and the heavens are the works of thine hands.' And in John 5:19, 'Then answered Jesus and said unto them, Verily, verily, I say unto you, The Son can do nothing of himself, but what he seeth the Father do: for what things soever he doeth, these also doeth the Son likewise.' In Hebrews 1:3, it is said of him, 'Who being the brightness of his glory, and the express image of his person, and upholding all things by the word of his power.' And in Philippians 3:21, there is attributed unto him that mighty working whereby 'he is able even to subdue all things unto himself.' Moreover, in John 5:21, 'For as the Father raiseth up the dead, and quickeneth them; even so the Son quickeneth whom he will.' And the power of the Father is the power of the Son, as he saith in John 10:29-30, 'My Father, which gave them me, is greater than all; and no man is able to pluck them out of my Father's hand. I and my Father are one.' Yea, all things that the Father hath are his, as he declareth in John 17:10, 'And all mine are thine, and thine are mine; and I am glorified in them.'
  • Another divine work is salvation, for God himself doth testify in Isaiah 43:11, 'I, even I, am the Lord; and beside me there is no saviour.' And in Hosea 13:4, 'Yet I am the Lord thy God from the land of Egypt, and thou shalt know no god but me: for there is no saviour beside me.' He alone justifieth us, as it is written in Isaiah 53:11, 'By his knowledge shall my righteous servant justify many; for he shall bear their iniquities,' and in Romans 8:33, 'Who shall lay any thing to the charge of God's elect? It is God that justifieth.' He forgiveth sins, Mark 2:7, 'Why doth this man thus speak blasphemies? who can forgive sins but God only?' He bestoweth the Holy Spirit, John 16:7, 'Nevertheless I tell you the truth; It is expedient for you that I go away: for if I go not away, the Comforter will not come unto you; but if I depart, I will send him unto you.' And in John 20:22, 'And when he had said this, he breathed on them, and saith unto them, Receive ye the Holy Ghost.' Thus, Christ doth foretell things to come by his Spirit, as in 1 Peter 1:11, 'Searching what, or what manner of time the Spirit of Christ which was in them did signify,' and in Revelation 2:23, 'And I will kill her children with death; and all the churches shall know that I am he which searcheth the reins and hearts: and I will give unto every one of you according to your works.' He raiseth the dead, even as the Father doth, John 5:21, 'For as the Father raiseth up the dead, and quickeneth them; even so the Son quickeneth whom he will.' Yea, he raised himself from the dead, as he saith in John 2:19, 'Destroy this temple, and in three days I will raise it up,' and John 10:18, 'No man taketh it from me, but I lay it down of myself. I have power to lay it down, and I have power to take it again.' Unto God alone is this mighty power everywhere ascribed in the Scriptures, as in Psalm 72:18, 'Blessed be the Lord God, the God of Israel, who only doeth wondrous things,' and in Psalms 86 and 136.

Fourth Argument: The fourth sort of arguments is taken from that honour which is due unto God alone, and which is universally rendered unto Christ. Such honour is:

  • Divine worship. As it is written in Hebrews 1:6, 'And let all the angels of God worship him.' Even as the entire host of heaven, yea, every creature, doth worship him, Revelation 5:11-13, 'And I beheld, and I heard the voice of many angels round about the throne and the beasts and the elders: and the number of them was ten thousand times ten thousand, and thousands of thousands; saying with a loud voice, Worthy is the Lamb that was slain to receive power, and riches, and wisdom, and strength, and honour, and glory, and blessing. And every creature which is in heaven, and on the earth, and under the earth, and such as are in the sea, and all that are in them, heard I saying, Blessing, and honour, and glory, and power, be unto him that sitteth upon the throne, and unto the Lamb for ever and ever.' And Stephen, when he was dying, commended his spirit unto him, saying, 'Lord Jesus, receive my spirit,' Acts 7:59. Moreover, honour equal to that of the Father is accorded unto Christ, by his own command, John 5:21-23, 'For as the Father raiseth up the dead, and quickeneth them; even so the Son quickeneth whom he will. For the Father judgeth no man, but hath committed all judgment unto the Son: that all men should honour the Son, even as they honour the Father. He that honoureth not the Son honoureth not the Father which hath sent him.' For herein is not spoken of a mere likeness, but of an equality, as is shown by the equality of their works, from which Christ doth infer this truth. That such worship and glory are due unto God alone, Christ himself doth testify in Matthew 4:10, 'Then saith Jesus unto him, Get thee hence, Satan: for it is written, Thou shalt worship the Lord thy God, and him only shalt thou serve.' And the Apostle, in Galatians 4:8, declareth that the Gentiles were idolaters, 'Howbeit then, when ye knew not God, ye did service unto them which by nature are no gods.'
  • Another such honour is faith in Christ, which is required of all who would be saved. As it is written, John 3:16, 'For God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in him should not perish, but have everlasting life.' And John 14:1, 'Let not your heart be troubled: ye believe in God, believe also in me.' Furthermore, we are baptized into his name, Matthew 28:19, 'Go ye therefore, and teach all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost.' Whereas no one can be baptized into the name of a mere creature, as Paul affirmeth in 1 Corinthians 1:13, 'Is Christ divided? was Paul crucified for you? or were ye baptized in the name of Paul?' We place our hope in him, as foretold in Genesis 49:10, 'Unto him shall the gathering of the people be,' and in Romans 15:12, 'And again, Esaias saith, There shall be a root of Jesse, and he that shall rise to reign over the Gentiles; in him shall the Gentiles trust.' And in 1 Corinthians 15:19, 'If in this life only we have hope in Christ, we are of all men most miserable.'

Fifth and Final Argument: The fifth and final argument for the essential unity of the Son with the Father is drawn from a comparison of the Old and New Testaments, wherein those things which are spoken of the true God of Israel in the Old are applied unto Christ in the New. Let us consider these few examples:

  • In Numbers 21:5-6, it is said that the people spake against God, and the Lord sent fiery serpents among them; and in Psalm 95:8-9, 'Harden not your heart, as in the provocation, and as in the day of temptation in the wilderness: when your fathers tempted me, proved me, and saw my work.' Yet the Apostle Paul, in 1 Corinthians 10:9, saith, 'Neither let us tempt Christ, as some of them also tempted, and were destroyed of serpents.'
  • Likewise, in Psalm 68:18, David speaketh of the God of Israel, 'Thou hast ascended on high, thou hast led captivity captive: thou hast received gifts for men;' but the Apostle Paul applieth this unto Christ in Ephesians 4:8, 'Wherefore he saith, When he ascended up on high, he led captivity captive, and gave gifts unto men.' And in verse 7, 'But unto every one of us is given grace according to the measure of the gift of Christ.'
  • So also, Psalm 97:7, 'Worship him, all ye gods,' which the Apostle citeth in Hebrews 1:6, 'And let all the angels of God worship him.' And Psalm 102:25, 'Of old hast thou laid the foundation of the earth: and the heavens are the work of thy hands,' which the same Apostle applieth unto Christ in Hebrews 1:10, 'And, Thou, Lord, in the beginning hast laid the foundation of the earth; and the heavens are the works of thine hands.'
  • Furthermore, in Isaiah 6:1, 'In the year that king Uzziah died I saw also the Lord sitting upon a throne, high and lifted up, and his train filled the temple,' and the Seraphim cried, 'Holy, holy, holy, is the Lord of hosts.' Yet John 12:41 saith, 'These things said Esaias, when he saw his glory, and spake of him,' that is, of Christ.
  • And in Isaiah 45:23, 'I have sworn by myself, the word is gone out of my mouth in righteousness, and shall not return, That unto me every knee shall bow, every tongue shall swear.' Nevertheless, the Apostle Paul, in Romans 14:10-11, declareth, 'But why dost thou judge thy brother? or why dost thou set at nought thy brother? for we shall all stand before the judgment seat of Christ. For it is written, As I live, saith the Lord, every knee shall bow to me, and every tongue shall confess to God.'

V. Christ is Also Very Man.

JUNIUS: Thus far we have spoken of the divine nature; now we turn to the human nature of Christ, which we affirm to be as truly his as his divinity, insomuch that he took upon him our nature in all respects, even with those infirmities which are without sin, though they be the consequence of sin, as being part of the punishment thereof. For since our nature consisteth not of the soul alone, nor of the body alone, but of both united, so also in Christ are found both soul and body, each with their essential properties:

  • First, that Christ possessed a true human soul, and not merely the divine Logos in place of a soul, as the heretic Apollinaris taught, is attested by Scripture; for it is written that he had a soul distinct from his divinity, and that this soul had its proper faculties. For Christ sorrowed, saying, 'My soul is exceeding sorrowful, even unto death,' Matthew 26:38. And the faculties of his soul are shown to be truly human, as Luke recordeth that he 'increased in wisdom and stature, and in favour with God and man,' Luke 2:52, which pertaineth to the human intellect. Moreover, he manifesteth that he hath a will distinct from the divine will, when he prayeth, 'Nevertheless not my will, but thine, be done,' Luke 22:42.
  • As for his body, it was not a mere appearance or phantom, as Marcion falsely taught; for if it had the essential properties of a body, why should it not be called a true body? It was palpable, as he said to his disciples after his resurrection, 'Handle me, and see; for a spirit hath not flesh and bones, as ye see me have,' Luke 24:39. And it was locally circumscribed, as it is said in Acts 3:21, 'Whom the heaven must receive until the times of restitution of all things.' This is beyond doubt, for when Thomas doubted, suspecting some ghostly apparition, Christ bade him touch his hands and side. Indeed, an imaginary or fantastical suffering could never have been a true and sufficient satisfaction for the sins of men.

TRELCH: The human nature of Christ is that whereby he shareth the same essence with us, save only in the manner of its subsistence, that is, in respect of personality, and in being free from the corrupt accidents or sins which mar our substance. For it was meet for the purpose of the incarnation that he should take upon him all natural infirmities, sin excepted. For some infirmities are merely pitiable, as Augustine termeth them, while others are damnable, or, as Damascene saith, blameworthy and detestable. Christ took upon him the former, for they did not hinder his perfection, knowledge, or grace, as it is written, 'And the Word was made flesh, and dwelt among us, (and we beheld his glory, the glory as of the only begotten of the Father,) full of grace and truth,' John 1:14; and 'God was manifest in the flesh,' 1 Timothy 3:16; and 'Who in the days of his flesh, when he had offered up prayers and supplications with strong crying and tears unto him that was able to save him from death, and was heard in that he feared,' Hebrews 5:7. But he took not the latter, for they would have been an impediment to our redemption.

VI. He Took Upon Him Human Nature from His Mother Mary, by the Working of the Holy Ghost.

WAL: But here certain Anabaptists do raise an objection, acknowledging indeed that Christ is very man, yet denying that he derived his origin from mankind, but rather from heaven. To this we reply, that although Christ was conceived by the power of the Holy Ghost, nevertheless he was truly conceived of the flesh and blood of Mary. This is proven:

  1. For he is called the seed of the woman, Genesis 3:15; the seed of Abraham, Genesis 22:18; the son of Judah, Hebrews 7:14; the son of David, Matthew 22:42; of the loins of David, Acts 2:30; of the fathers according to the flesh, Romans 9:5; the fruit of Mary's womb, Luke 1:42; for she carried him in her womb nine months, and gave him suck, and so forth.
  2. From the genealogy of Christ, as recorded in Matthew chapter 1 and Luke chapter 3. For what purpose would the lineage be traced by Matthew from Abraham unto Christ, and by Luke from Adam unto Christ, if he were not descended from them?

Objection: They object that he descended only through Mary, not that he is of her substance.

Response: But this is erroneous, for it is said that he is of Mary, even as others are of their fathers. Moreover, he is termed the fruit of her womb, Luke 1:42; Mary is called his mother; he is said to be made of a woman, Galatians 4:4; all which plainly indicate his true humanity derived from her. He is of the fruit of David's loins, Acts 2:30, even as Levi is said to have been in the loins of Abraham when he was tithed by Melchizedek, Hebrews 7:5,10.

AMES: Yet it is most true and certain that Christ was the son of Mary, and the promised seed of the woman. Nor does this imply that there are two distinct sonships in Christ, or two sons united. For that temporal sonship, whereby he is related to his mother, is but a relation of reason. Indeed, Christ's human nature had a real connection to Mary, as to its cause. But sonship pertaineth not to the nature, but to the person alone: nevertheless, that relation is of the human nature to the person, and of Mary to that nature, so that it may be truly and properly said that Mary was the mother of God. The efficient cause of this conception was not man, wherefore the blessed Mary was both mother and virgin, as it is written in Matthew 1:23, 'Behold, a virgin shall be with child, and shall bring forth a son, and they shall call his name Emmanuel, which being interpreted is, God with us,' fulfilling the prophecy of Isaiah 7:14. But the Holy Ghost was the agent in this conception. Yet Christ cannot be called the son of the Holy Ghost, not even in respect of his humanity, for as man he is not of the same nature as the Holy Ghost, nor doth sonship belong to the nature, but to the person, that he might bear the title of son.

VII. Thus, the Divine Person of the Son, Having Taken Flesh, Did Unite Unto Himself the Human Nature, So That Both Natures Are Joined in One Person.

PROFESSOR: Now, the incarnation is that wondrous work of God whereby the Son of God, in accordance with the divine dispensation ordained by the Father, and by himself, and by the Holy Ghost, did humble himself, and took upon him true, entire, perfect, and holy flesh from the virgin Mary, through the mighty working of the Holy Spirit, uniting it unto himself in the unity of his person: in such wise that this flesh hath no independent existence apart from the Son of God, but is verily upheld and sustained by him and in him. Thus, two perfect natures are conjoined, without change, without confusion, without division, without separation, from which union the person of Christ is constituted both God and man. And this was necessary, that he might fully execute the office of a mediator before God, reconciling and uniting mankind unto God, and particularly reconciling and uniting the elect unto God, bestowing upon them righteousness, holiness, and life everlasting, thereby manifesting the justice of God and setting forth the praise of his mercy.

TRELCH: The groundwork of this union is the incarnation itself; the efficient cause thereof, in its inception, as the Schoolmen term it, is the entire Trinity: but in its termination, it is Christ himself, who became that which he was not, whilst continuing to be that which he was. The incarnation hath two parts: conception and birth; both of which are ordinary in respect of the reality of the matter, for Christ took upon him a nature like unto ours, derived from the substance of Mary; yet extraordinary in respect of the manner, that is, in the formation within Mary's womb, in the assumption of the nature, in its sanctification, and finally in its perfection. The nature of this union we may discern by its definition and distinction. For it is a union personal, not of persons, but of two natures in Christ, and that not a natural union: it is not like the union of superiors with inferiors, nor of accidents with substances, nor of a part with the whole; but it is such that the two natures are united in the person mediately, and the human nature is united immediately unto the person, in a manner most mysterious and intimate. As it is written in 1 Timothy 3:16, 'And without controversy great is the mystery of godliness: God was manifest in the flesh;' and in Galatians 4:4, 'But when the fulness of the time was come, God sent forth his Son, made of a woman, made under the law;' and in Colossians 2:9, 'For in him dwelleth all the fulness of the Godhead bodily.' There are three ways in which things may be united:

  • Essentially, as when many things become one essence;
  • Accidentally, as when accidents are added to a subject;
  • Substantially, as when a substance, which otherwise would stand alone, is drawn into the being of another individual.

JUNIUS: Therefore, this union was effected in the person, not in the nature: and it is rightly defined as the most complete and substantial conjunction of two natures into one person. From this it is evident how each nature standeth: for the divine nature assumeth, and the human is assumed: not that from these two, as from parts, some third thing is compounded, but that the human nature, which before had no subsistence, is taken up by the Word into the unity of his person, and is made to subsist therein.

TRELCH: The unity of the person is demonstrated by three things:

  1. Testimony of Scripture: For Christ is called Immanuel, which being interpreted is, God with us, as the Prophet Isaiah foretold, Isaiah 7:14. The Angel declared unto Mary, 'The Holy Ghost shall come upon thee, and the power of the Highest shall overshadow thee: therefore also that holy thing which shall be born of thee shall be called the Son of God,' Luke 1:35. The Evangelist John saith, 'And the Word was made flesh, and dwelt among us, (and we beheld his glory, the glory as of the only begotten of the Father,) full of grace and truth,' John 1:14. The Apostle Paul affirmeth, 'Whose are the fathers, and of whom as concerning the flesh Christ came, who is over all, God blessed for ever. Amen,' Romans 9:5.
  2. Purpose of the Incarnation: For that God and man might be united in covenant, it was needful that God and man should be united in one person, not merely by a participation of grace, but by the verity of nature; not by a confusion of substances, but by the unity of person.
  3. Attributes of Both Natures: By the attributes of both natures being ascribed unto the same subject; for as those things which are proper unto the human nature are not attributed unto the divine nature, nor those which are divine unto the human, so all things are truly and properly predicated of the person, according to each nature. As in Acts 20:28, 'Take heed therefore unto yourselves, and to all the flock, over the which the Holy Ghost hath made you overseers, to feed the church of God, which he hath purchased with his own blood.' And in 1 Corinthians 2:8, 'Which none of the princes of this world knew: for had they known it, they would not have crucified the Lord of glory.' Therefore, one and the same person is both eternal and not eternal; infinite and finite; possessing all divine properties as God, and all human properties as man; the divine from eternity, the human assumed in time; both natures being real, yet without transference, so that as man he is God.

WAL: The Nestorians did err, teaching that there are two sons and two persons in Christ, namely, God and man; and that the latter alone was born, suffered, and rose again; whence they held that the virgin Mary is χριστοτόκος, that is, the mother of Christ, but not θεοτόκος, the mother of God, and that she brought forth a mere man, unto whom the Son of God was subsequently united in divers manners and by sundry degrees. The Eutychians, on the other hand, though they admitted two natures before the union, yet maintained that after the union they were transformed into one nature, and that this single nature bore all the properties of both, some in reality, others only in semblance.

ZANCHIUS: We do justly reject, in accord with the Schoolmen, the notion that the person of Christ, strictly speaking, is compounded of the divine nature, which is infinite and most simple, and the human nature, which is finite and infinitely less than the divine, as though from two distinct parts. As Thomas Aquinas hath stated in his Summa Theologica, third part, question 4, article 2.

VIII. Both Natures in Christ Do Retain Their Distinct Properties, and There Is No Transference of Omniscience, Omnipotence, Ubiquity, or the Quality of Being Worshipable Unto the Human Nature.

PISCATOR: There is a controversy in the Church at this day, whether certain attributes of the divine nature in Christ—such as omnipresence or ubiquity, omniscience, and omnipotence—are imparted unto his human nature, in such sort that it is as omnipresent, omniscient, and omnipotent as the divine nature itself. This we deny. And our reason is this: the Scriptures do plainly declare that our Lord Jesus Christ is very man, made like unto us in all things, sin only excepted, as it is written in Hebrews 2:17, 'Wherefore in all things it behoved him to be made like unto his brethren,' and in Hebrews 4:15, 'For we have not an high priest which cannot be touched with the feeling of our infirmities; but was in all points tempted like as we are, yet without sin.' Now, if those divine attributes were communicated unto his human nature, then Christ would not be true man; for his human nature, by such communication, would be transformed into the divine nature. For the attributes of the divine nature are in truth identical with the divine essence. Therefore, whosoever receiveth those attributes receiveth the very essence of God. Moreover, if these attributes were imparted, then all the other divine attributes would also be imparted, including eternity and infinity. For the attributes of the divine essence cannot be separated one from another, since they are the very essence of God, which is most simple and indivisible. But eternity and infinity are not communicated unto the human nature; this even our adversaries do admit.

WAL: But Brentius and the other Ubiquitarians, while they acknowledge two natures in Christ, do nevertheless maintain that the hypostatic union consisteth in the pouring out or communication of the divine attributes unto the human nature, particularly omnipresence, or at the least, that such communication doth necessarily follow from the union. To this we reply, that the hypostatic union doth not consist in any real transference or communication of attributes, nor doth such communication necessarily ensue:

  1. For since the natures remain distinct and entire after the union, it followeth that their respective attributes also remain distinct and entire. This premise is granted by the Ubiquitarians themselves, and we have proven it from numerous passages of Holy Scripture against the Anabaptists, showing that one nature is not changed into the other nor abolished, as may be seen in John 3:13, 'No man hath ascended up to heaven, but he that came down from heaven, even the Son of man which is in heaven;' Romans 1:3, 'Concerning his Son Jesus Christ our Lord, which was made of the seed of David according to the flesh;' Romans 9:5, 'Whose are the fathers, and of whom as concerning the flesh Christ came, who is over all, God blessed for ever;' 1 Timothy 3:16, 'God was manifest in the flesh;' Hebrews 9:14, 'How much more shall the blood of Christ, who through the eternal Spirit offered himself without spot to God, purge your conscience from dead works to serve the living God?' and 1 Peter 3:18, 'For Christ also hath once suffered for sins, the just for the unjust, that he might bring us to God, being put to death in the flesh, but quickened by the Spirit.' The conclusion is evident, for it is agreed by all that attributes necessarily accompany their nature; and the divine attributes are the very essence of God, as all orthodox divines do confess.
  2. For the Scriptures do clearly affirm that in Christ, after his incarnation, the attributes of each nature remained unchanged; therefore, the divine attributes are not infused into the human nature. This is proven because a single divine attribute would inevitably nullify the corresponding human attribute.
