Thus, they claim that Christ was made omniscient even in his human nature; but the Scriptures testify that he was ignorant of certain things, as in Mark 13:32, 'But of that day and that hour knoweth no man, no, not the angels which are in heaven, neither the Son, but the Father;' and that he 'increased in wisdom,' Luke 2:52. Likewise, God is incorruptible, unchangeable, and immortal, as in Romans 1:23, 'And changed the glory of the uncorruptible God into an image made like to corruptible man;' James 1:17, 'Every good gift and every perfect gift is from above, and cometh down from the Father of lights, with whom is no variableness, neither shadow of turning;' and 1 Timothy 6:16, 'Who only hath immortality, dwelling in the light which no man can approach unto;' but the human nature of Christ was subject to suffering and death before his resurrection. Hence, it necessarily followeth that these divine attributes were not transferred unto the human nature.
  3. If some attributes were communicated, then all must have been communicated; for all divine attributes are inseparably connected, being one with the divine essence. But it is impossible that eternity, simplicity, and infinity should befit a body born of Mary in time and possessing human dimensions.
  4. If the personal union consisted in the communication of essential divine attributes, then all three persons of the Trinity would have been incarnate; but this is absurd. The reason is, that the essential attributes are common to all three persons, as all sound theologians do recognize.
  5. It would result that there are two beings who are omnipotent, two who are omniscient, two who are infinite: one nature possessing these attributes inherently, and another by communication; one from eternity, the other in time.

Objection: But the Apostle declareth in Colossians 2:9, 'For in him dwelleth all the fulness of the Godhead bodily.' Therefore, all the divine attributes dwell in him.

Response:

  1. I grant the whole truth of the text: for the divine attributes do dwell in Christ's human nature in the same manner as the Godhead itself, which is the essence of the Son, doth dwell therein: that is, by virtue of the hypostatic union with the human nature, yet in such a way that the indweller and the thing indwelt are plainly distinct: hence, the attributes of the indweller and of the thing indwelt remain distinct.
  2. Moreover, some do interpret this passage as referring to the gifts bestowed upon the human nature, which are termed 'all the fulness of the Godhead' in comparison with others who have received but a portion; and 'all' is to be understood relatively, not absolutely, in respect of those gifts which are requisite for the accomplishment of universal salvation, as the subsequent words appear to suggest, verse 10, 'And ye are complete in him, which is the head of all principality and power.'

Second Objection: Yet divine attributes are at times ascribed unto Christ in his humanity. For instance, in Matthew 28:18, 'All power is given unto me in heaven and in earth.'

Response: If from this there were to follow a real communication of attributes, there would also follow a real communication of essence, since it is said in Acts 20:28, 'To feed the church of God, which he hath purchased with his own blood.' But these expressions are to be understood in respect of the union of the natures, not as implying any real pouring out or transference of attributes. Furthermore, the word used is ἔξεσία, which signifieth authority, not δύναμις, which is power.

Instance: But it is said that power (δύναμις) is also given unto him. For he forgiveth sins as the Son of man, Matthew 9:6, 'But that ye may know that the Son of man hath power on earth to forgive sins,' and in Revelation 5:12, 'Saying with a loud voice, Worthy is the Lamb that was slain to receive power (δύναμιν), and riches, and wisdom, and strength, and honour, and glory, and blessing.'

Response: These things are said of him in respect of his person, that is, he is worthy to have these titles ascribed unto him. And he forgiveth sins as God; moreover, as mediator, he doth it by virtue of his merit, and as the instrument of the Godhead, applying outwardly his merit through the word. The case is different with essential attributes, of which we shall speak hereafter.

Second Instance: Yet he is worshiped.

Response: The person of Christ is worshiped with a single act of worship, as he is both God and man: the human nature is the object of our contemplation in worship, but not the direct object of worship itself: neither are there two separate acts of worship; for when in one person there are two natures or offices, the honour is rendered according to the higher nature or office, not the lower, even as we see in the case of a king, who is honoured as king, though he be also a man.

Third Instance: It is said that the flesh of Christ giveth life, as in John 6:51, 'I am the living bread which came down from heaven: if any man eat of this bread, he shall live for ever: and the bread that I will give is my flesh, which I will give for the life of the world.'

Response: This is so by reason of its union with the Godhead: moreover, by the merit of Christ, and according to God's appointment, that whosoever believeth in him should be justified and quickened.

Question of Ubiquity: It is inquired whether, by this union, ubiquity is imparted unto the human nature of Christ, as certain Ubiquitarians of our time do hold, who assert that the communication of these attributes is a consequence of the union, and in this they follow the opinion of Brentius and others, who infer it from Christ's sitting at the right hand of God.

But we purpose to show that it proceedeth from neither of these; For the Scriptures do plainly declare that the humanity of Christ is not everywhere present. As in John 11:15, 'And I am glad for your sakes that I was not there, to the intent ye may believe;' Matthew 28:6, 'He is not here; for he is risen, as he said. Come, see the place where the Lord lay;' Matthew 26:11, 'For ye have the poor always with you; but me ye have not always;' John 16:28, 'I came forth from the Father, and am come into the world: again, I leave the world, and go to the Father;' Luke 24:51, 'And it came to pass, while he blessed them, he was parted from them, and carried up into heaven;' Acts 1:11, 'Which also said, Ye men of Galilee, why stand ye gazing up into heaven? this same Jesus, which is taken up from you into heaven, shall so come in like manner as ye have seen him go into heaven;' and 2 Corinthians 5:6, 'Therefore we are always confident, knowing that, whilst we are at home in the body, we are absent from the Lord.'

Instance: But they may reply that these scriptures speak of his visible presence, not of an invisible presence.

Response: This is not so:

  1. For Christ's body is not invisible, as he said to his disciples, 'Behold my hands and my feet, that it is I myself: handle me, and see; for a spirit hath not flesh and bones, as ye see me have,' Luke 24:39.
  2. Even if he were present somewhere invisibly, it could not be said absolutely that he is not there, or that he hath departed from the world: for the soul is invisibly present in the body, yet we do not say that the soul is absent when it is there; similarly, God is invisibly present in the world, but we cannot say that he is not present.
  3. Omnipresence is an attribute proper unto God, whereby he doth distinguish himself from all created beings; and by this attribute, all the orthodox Fathers have demonstrated the deity of the Son and of the Holy Ghost: therefore, it cannot be shared by Christ's human nature. This is confirmed by Jeremiah 23:24, 'Can any hide himself in secret places that I shall not see him? saith the Lord. Do not I fill heaven and earth? saith the Lord.' And in Psalm 139:7, 'Whither shall I go from thy spirit? or whither shall I flee from thy presence?' And Isaiah 66:1, 'Thus saith the Lord, The heaven is my throne, and the earth is my footstool.'
  4. For Christ's human nature consisteth of soul and body, and the body of divers members; if it were omnipresent, it would follow that there are many infinite things, and that some are greater than others, which is contrary to the nature of the infinite.
  5. Because the Scriptures do affirm that Christ shall remain in heaven until the day of judgment, as in Acts 1:11, 'This same Jesus, which is taken up from you into heaven, shall so come in like manner as ye have seen him go into heaven;' and Acts 3:21, 'Whom the heaven must receive until the times of restitution of all things;' and Philippians 3:20, 'For our conversation is in heaven; from whence also we look for the Saviour, the Lord Jesus Christ.'

    6. Instance: But it is argued that Christ doth contain heaven, rather than that heaven containeth Christ.

    Response: This is absurd, for:

    1. The expression is altogether improper, as it would be strange to say that Christ containeth heaven.
    2. From the clause added, 'until the times of restitution of all things,' for it would imply that Christ shall relinquish his heavenly glory and majesty after the judgment, which is untrue.
  6. For it is contrary to the truth of Christ's body, since he was made like unto us in all things, as it is written in Hebrews 2:14, 'Forasmuch then as the children are partakers of flesh and blood, he also himself likewise took part of the same;' and therefore he is called the second Adam and is frequently referred to as man.
  7. Moreover, all the articles of our faith would be subverted. For if his body were ubiquitous, he could not have been conceived in the womb; nor could he truly move from one place to another, but only vanish; nor could his soul be separated from his body at death, nor could his soul be in paradise while his body lay in the grave; nor could he truly ascend into heaven, nor truly descend to judge the quick and the dead, and so forth.

Objection: Christ sitteth at the right hand of God, and since God is everywhere, therefore Christ is everywhere according to both his natures.

Response:

  1. This inference is invalid, for Stephen, when dying, said, 'Lord Jesus, receive my spirit,' Acts 7:59, and David commended his spirit into God's hands, Psalm 31:5; yet neither Stephen nor David is thereby omnipresent.
  2. Moreover, the phrase 'the right hand of God' is not to be understood literally in this context, for God is a spirit, and hath neither flesh nor bones; rather, it is a metaphorical expression denoting the highest state of glory and honour to which Christ was exalted by the Father after his suffering and ascension into heaven. This figure of speech is borrowed from the practice of earthly kings and rulers, who, when seated upon their thrones or presiding in judgment, do place at their right hand those whom they wish to honour above all others, or whom they make sharers in their dominion, as is the custom in all realms. Thus, King Solomon, when he sat upon his throne, set his mother at his right hand, 1 Kings 2:19. Likewise, in Psalm 45:9, 'Upon thy right hand did stand the queen in gold of Ophir.' And the mother of Zebedee's children besought Christ that her two sons might sit, the one on his right hand, and the other on his left, in his kingdom, Matthew 20:21. Therefore, Christ's sitting at the right hand of the Father doth not signify his natural and eternal glory as God, which he hath ever shared with the Father, for in that case the Holy Ghost would also be said to sit at God's right hand; but it denoteth his mediatorial and dispensational kingdom, wherein, as the God-man and our mediator, he is appointed by the Father to gather his Church. As it is written in Psalm 110:1, 'The Lord said unto my Lord, Sit thou at my right hand, until I make thine enemies thy footstool.' Which the Apostle Paul expoundeth, saying that all things are put under him, save only he who did put all things under him, 1 Corinthians 15:27. Thus, it pertaineth to his glory as mediator and to the economy of salvation, not to his essential divine glory.

Objection: If the human nature is not present wherever the divine nature is, then the divine nature is not united to the human nature in every place.

Response: This doth not follow. For it is enough that they are united in a particular place, even as the sun is joined to the sky, or the soul to the body.

Question of Omniscience: A second question ariseth between us and the Ubiquitarians: whether omniscience was not truly communicated unto Christ by means of the hypostatic union.

Not only the Ubiquitarians, but also the Papists, do press this point in their own fashion. Many among our divines do grant that in the human nature of Christ, from the very moment of his conception and the hypostatic union, there was present that beatific and infused knowledge in so perfect a degree that it could neither increase nor be augmented; and that he did advance only in knowledge acquired through experience. The Scholastics, following Peter Lombard in his Sentences, book 3, distinction 13, do affirm and define that this knowledge is blessed, whereby the essence of God and all things therein are beheld; and they maintain that the soul of Christ did contemplate the Word united unto it, and all things in the Word, from the instant of his creation and birth. But:

  1. The premise upon which the Scholastics and others rely is not certain: to wit, that they who see the essence of God do see all things in it. For this is not true even of the angels, as is evident from Mark 13:32, 'But of that day and that hour knoweth no man, no, not the angels which are in heaven, neither the Son, but the Father;' and from Ephesians 3:10, 'To the intent that now unto the principalities and powers in heavenly places might be known by the church the manifold wisdom of God;' and from Revelation 5:3, 'And no man in heaven, nor in earth, neither under the earth, was able to open the book, neither to look thereon.' Likewise, concerning the souls of the blessed, as in John 14:13, 'And whatsoever ye shall ask in my name, that will I do, that the Father may be glorified in the Son,' implying that they do not know all things; and Isaiah 63:9, 'In all their affliction he was afflicted, and the angel of his presence saved them;' and the reason is, that 'the things of God knoweth no man, but the Spirit of God,' 1 Corinthians 2:11, and those to whom he hath revealed them, as in Matthew 11:27, 'Neither knoweth any man the Father, save the Son, and he to whomsoever the Son will reveal him.' Therefore, the beatific vision doth not necessarily entail omniscience.
  2. It is inconsistent with the state of humiliation in which Christ was, who endured sorrows, torments, and adversities, and was subject unto death; which things are incompatible with the beatific vision. Indeed, for the sake of his passion, he is said to have been 'made a little lower than the angels,' Hebrews 2:9.
  3. There are clear passages in Scripture which attribute some ignorance unto Christ, such as Luke 2:40, 'And the child grew, and waxed strong in spirit, filled with wisdom: and the grace of God was upon him;' and verse 52, 'And Jesus increased in wisdom and stature, and in favour with God and man.' These cannot be interpreted merely as a manifestation of knowledge, for he advanced in wisdom in the same manner as he did in age, the construction of the verb being the same. So also in Mark 13:32, 'But of that day and that hour knoweth no man, no, not the angels which are in heaven, neither the Son, but the Father.' The word 'knoweth' hath but one meaning here, and the statement is climactic. For otherwise, it would imply that the angels are ignorant in such a way that they do not reveal it, and that the Father also doth not know. Furthermore, it is altogether unusual to say that someone doth not know a thing because he chooseth not to reveal it; such a notion is but a Jesuitical device to conceal deceit.
  4. Christ was made like unto us in all things: he grew in age, he grew in body, and was tempted in all points as we are, yet without sin. And ignorance is not sin.

Therefore, we conclude that Christ was endued with the spirit of knowledge from his mother's womb, and that in such measure as was requisite for his office; and that he did advance, not by external revelation, but by an internal communication from his divine nature; so that, as he is to be the judge of the quick and the dead, all the secrets of our consciences shall be laid open before him: for he shall pronounce sentence also as man.

POLANUS: In Luke 2:40, Bellarmine doth erroneously commend the error of the Vulgate translation, which rendereth the Greek participle τυληρόρθω as 'full,' whereas the Greek clearly showeth that in the child Jesus, wisdom did gradually increase, both through experience and acquisition. Likewise, in Luke 2:52, 'And Jesus increased in wisdom and stature, and in favour with God and man,' Bellarmine doth grossly misinterpret the text, claiming that Jesus advanced only in the estimation of men, as he more and more revealed his wisdom unto them. But in truth, he did advance in wisdom in his human nature, both by the outpouring of the Spirit and by knowledge gained through experience and study.

Question of Adorability: It is inquired whether the quality of being worshipable is also imparted unto his flesh.

The safest course is to affirm that Christ is worshiped with a single act of worship as the God-man, the reason and ground thereof being his divine nature, even as it was decreed in the Council of Ephesus, in the eighth anathema: 'If any man shall dare to say that the man who was assumed ought to be worshiped together with God the Word, and glorified together with him, and with him called God, as one with another (for the addition of “with” will necessarily introduce this sense), and will not rather honour the Emmanuel with one adoration, and pay him one praise, as the Word was made flesh, let him be anathema.'

Further Inquiry: Here the question is raised: whether Christ, in his capacity as mediator, is to be adored with religious worship, and consequently, whether in his mediatorial office there lieth the fundamental reason (that for which) and the formal reason (that under which) of divine worship; or whether he is to be worshiped only insofar as he is God absolute, together with the Father and the Holy Ghost.

To this, it seemeth, with due respect to the opinions of others, that the answer should be thus:

  • That the ultimate and primary ground and cause of our invoking God is that God, considered absolutely and as subsisting in three persons, is the first cause and origin of all things.
  • Nevertheless, it is beyond doubt that the same God, whether considered absolutely or in his persons relatively and individually, hath also furnished other motives and reasons for worship, invocation, thanksgiving, and the like, particularly unto his people, by reason of which he is to be worshiped in a special manner.

Example: For instance, the deliverance of the children of Israel from Egypt by the outstretched arm of God is frequently cited by the prophets as a particular reason for confidence, thanksgiving, prayer, and the like; and hence, in the first commandment, it is said, 'I am the Lord thy God, which have brought thee out of the land of Egypt, out of the house of bondage.' And for this cause, he is often invoked under the title of the Redeemer and Deliverer of Israel, because in bestowing this mercy upon them, he did manifest the attributes of his Godhead for their welfare and for the punishment of their foes. Therefore, in like manner, Christ, the Son of God, as the Mediator and Redeemer of his people, is to be called upon, and is so called upon throughout the Scriptures.

VOETIUS: Christ, in his humanity and as mediator, in the flesh and with the flesh, in and with his mediatorial office, is to be adored: in such wise that the object of our worship is the person of Christ, with all that pertaineth unto him, or the entire Christ; for honour is properly rendered unto the whole subsisting being, as Thomas Aquinas doth rightly observe in his Summa Theologica, third part, question 25, article 1. Neither are the natures to be separated, nor any attributes detached from the person in our discourse.

  1. In him who is worshiped, two aspects may be considered: namely, the one to whom the honour of worship is given, and the reasons for that worship. In one act of worship, there may be, on our part, various motives or reasons, broadly speaking: so long as we do not posit multiple proximate, adequate, and fundamental causes of the act, which are the formal reasons, and from which the formal quality of worshipability ariseth in the object itself. For that formal reason is singular, to wit, the surpassing excellence and majesty of the eternal Godhead, which is supreme, primary, and independent.
  2. The flesh of Christ is worshiped not in itself, nor for its own sake, but by reason of the Godhead which is conjoined and united unto it; thus, the ultimate object of our worship is not the flesh, but the Godhead. As Thomas saith in the aforesaid article, 'We do not say that the hand of a man is honoured, but that the man is honoured.' And if it be sometimes said that a man's hand is honoured, this is not because the hand itself is honoured, but because through the hand the whole man is honoured. This is the judgment of the Council of Ephesus, as expressed in its anathemas and in the synodal letter, and of Athanasius in his fifth oration and third dialogue against the Arians, and of Cyril in his second book on John, chapter 92, and in his work on the Incarnation of the Only Begotten, chapter 26; which view our theologians do follow in their disputations against the Ubiquitists.
  3. The formal object of worship is that in which the act of worship ultimately terminates and is primarily grounded, and to which it is ultimately referred. For example, a man seeth not as a man or as a rational being, but as a sentient being; where the final analysis is to the faculty of sense, not to humanity or rationality; hence, the formal reason is the sentient faculty, not the rational or human nature: and we say that a man seeth as a sentient being, not as a rational being, or under that formal aspect of being human. Similarly, the worship of Christ as mediator doth not ultimately resolve into his mediatorial office, but into his deity. And we worship the whole Christ as mediator, and thus regarded by us as mediator, endowed with all his qualities, offices, and virtues, without separating anything: yet not precisely as mediator, in such a way that his mediation or any other thing besides his deity is the formal object of our worship. If some do but loosely employ the term 'as' or 'insofar as,' and mean nothing more than that he is considered as mediator, not that his mediation is the formal and ultimate object, they are guilty of imprecise speech, and if they insist upon it, of mere verbal contention.

IX. From This Union of the Two Natures, There Ariseth Divers Manners of Speaking Concerning Christ, Whether in Reference to His Person or to His Natures, Which Is Called the Communication of Properties.

MELANCTHON: It is meet for godly men to take heed, for the sake of unity, to speak in agreement with the Church, and not without sound reasons; for the ancient Church did approve certain forms of expression and reject others. Let us therefore avoid contentious wrangling, and hold fast to the accepted forms with due reverence and authority. This statement is false: 'The divine nature is human.' But these are true: 'God is man, the Word is man, Christ is man, Christ is God, God was born of a virgin, God suffered;' for the person in whom the divine nature is united to the human nature by a personal union is he who was born and crucified. This manner of speaking, when we attribute to the concrete person what belongeth to one nature, is termed the communication of properties, that is, a predication wherein the attributes of the natures are properly ascribed to the person; thus, the Son of God is the Redeemer, not merely the human nature.

JUNIUS: From the distinct subsistence of the two natures and their most intimate union in the person, there ariseth three modes of speech:

  1. One proper, whereby that which pertaineth peculiarly to each nature is ascribed unto it, as suffering to the human nature; and whereby that which is common to both natures in the person is attributed to the whole person, as that Christ is the mediator.
  2. An improper mode, by way of synecdoche, when that which belongeth to the entire person, such as being the mediator, is attributed to one nature, as to the human.
  3. A most improper mode, when that which is proper to one nature is predicated of the other nature in the concrete, the name denoting the whole person: by which figure it is true to say, 'God purchased the church with his own blood,' Acts 20:28; and 'they crucified the Lord of glory,' 1 Corinthians 2:8. This manner of expression, noted by the Fathers, was termed the conjunction of names and the communication of properties.

AMES: And hence it followeth that the communication of these properties, as touching predication or attribution, is such that the properties of one nature are ascribed either to the whole person, as when Christ is said to have died, which was proper to the human nature, or to have been in the beginning, which was proper to the divine nature; or to the other nature by reason of the person, as when God is said to have been received up into glory, 1 Timothy 3:16, or crucified, 1 Corinthians 2:8, which things pertain not properly to the divine nature, but to the human. And those things which are proper to the whole person are ascribed separately to one nature: as when the man Christ is called the mediator between God and men, 1 Timothy 2:5, which belongeth not to Christ as man alone, but as he is both God and man. And as this communion doth properly respect the person of Christ, not the natures considered in themselves, so this communication, which consisteth in predication, doth respect God or man in the concrete, not the Godhead or humanity in the abstract. Therefore, the communication of properties is not merely verbal, nor yet so real that the property of one nature passeth into the other as to intrinsic possession and use.

X. The Office of Christ Is in General Twofold, to Be a Mediator, and a Saviour, That Is, Jesus.

MACC. It is to be noted here that the Mediator and the Saviour are the same, for the end of mediation is salvation; the mediation itself is the means to the end: and so these are two names of one and the same office, Mediator and Saviour, one derived from the end, the other from the means.

XI. To Which He Was Anointed by God, or Endued with a Singular Calling and Gifts, That Is, Christ.

JUN. The end of mediation is that He might be Jesus, that is, our Saviour (Matthew 1, Acts 4), for He saveth His people from their sins: and no other name is given under heaven whereby we must be saved. The means are gifts and calling: in respect whereof He is called by the Hebrews Messiah, by the Greeks Christos, and by us Messias, Christ, the Anointed: as in the Apostles’ Creed we profess to believe in Jesus Christ.

ZANCH. We believe, finally, that Christ, as He is God, is simply wise, and so of all other attributes: so, as He is man, He was endowed by the Father with power and knowledge, far exceeding, by almost infinite degrees, the power and knowledge of all created things, both celestial and terrestrial, yet finite; and the same of other gifts and virtues, charity, prudence, fortitude, justice, grace, truth, and others, concerning which Isaiah saith, And the Spirit of the Lord shall rest upon Him (Isaiah 11:2). And John, Full of grace and truth (John 1:14). Likewise Luke, He increased in wisdom and grace before God and men (Luke 2:52).

AMES. The office of Christ is that which He undertook to procure salvation for men (1 Timothy 1:15). This is a faithful saying, and worthy of all acceptation, that Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners. For those who deny that the proper end proposed by God and Christ in this mystery was the salvation of men, deprive God and Christ of their honor and men of their consolation. In this are two things to be considered: the calling to this function, and the function itself (Hebrews 5:4-6). No man taketh this honor unto himself, but he that is called of God, as was Aaron. So also Christ, etc. The calling is an action of God, eminently of the Father, whereby, by a certain singular covenant entered into, He destined His Son to this office. This covenant is expressed, But if Christ should offer Himself a sacrifice for sin, then He should see His seed, prolong His days, and the pleasure of the Lord should prosper by Him (Isaiah 53:10). This calling, therefore, containeth election, preordination, and mission. My chosen (Isaiah 42:1). Foreknown before the foundation of the world (1 Peter 1:20). God sent His Son into the world (John 3:17). It is called in Scripture sealing (John 6:27), sanctification (John 10:36), anointing (Isaiah 61:1, Psalm 45:8, Hebrews 1:9), and gift (John 3:16). Election respecteth the end; preordination, the means; mission, the execution itself, of mere grace, without any condition foreseen either in men or in Christ Himself. All things that Christ did or suffered were predetermined, even as to all circumstances (Luke 22:22). The Son of man goeth as it was determined (Acts 4:28). To do whatsoever Thy hand and Thy counsel determined before to be done.

In the first instant of this conception, Christ, according to His human nature, received the fullness of all grace, as to the first act (John 1:14). Full of grace and truth (Luke 2:40). He was filled with knowledge: so that it could be increased as to secondary acts, and by extension to new objects (Luke 2:52). He increased in wisdom. Hence Christ was indeed enriched with blessedness from the instant of conception, but so as, in the manner of wayfarers, He made progress therein, until He attained to the highest exaltation.

MACC. The human nature was imbued with the fullness of all the gifts of the Holy Spirit without measure, in the most excellent degree that can fall to a creature.

XII. Christ Jesus is the One and Perfect Mediator.

AMES: This Mediator is the only Jesus Christ. As it is written in Acts, chapter 4, verse 12, “Neither is there salvation in any other: for there is none other name under heaven given among men, whereby we must be saved.”

TRELCH: The matter of this office is considered in two ways. First, subjectively, and it encompasseth both natures of Christ, as in John 6:33, not separately, but conjoined. For the parts of mediation are twofold: those toward God and those toward us. Therefore, Christ must be, as in office, so in person, a Mediator between God and us, communicating by nature with both, that He might be a Mediator in office between both. Then, secondly, effectively: and these are all the actions which, as God, He performeth divinely; as man, humanly; and as Mediator, unitedly and indivisibly. Whence they are called theandric, because as there is one agent, so there is one effect of the operations of both natures. The operation belongeth to the person; the principles of operations are the natures.

XIII. And He is Mediator According to Both Natures.

TRELCH: In the office of Christ, three things are to be distinguished: His calling, which He had immediately from God in His person; the gifts from His calling, which He received mediately in His human nature; and the administration, which belonged to His person according to both natures. These three were signified by the external anointing in the Old Testament. The principle of mediation is considered either absolutely or relatively. Absolutely, the principle is the person of Christ, God and man. Relatively and distinctly, the principle in the same person is, first, the Logos according to His divine nature; second, the human nature subsisting in the person. According to His nature, He is equal to the Father; but according to the economy, He is less than the Father. We must distinguish between the whole Christ and the whole of Christ: the former referreth to His person, the latter to His natures. For what is true of the whole Christ is not always conveniently or truly said of the whole of Christ.

WAL: This is a question of the utmost importance: whether Christ is our Mediator according to both natures? Stancarus wished that only the human nature of Christ was mediatorial. Bellarmine concedeth that the person of Christ was the Mediator, but only according to His human nature; and therefore, in the divine nature, or rather in the person of the Son of God, there is only dignity, not properly efficacy, in the mediatorial actions. Or, as they say, the suppositum is indeed the proximate principle of these actions, but the divine nature is not the formal principle of any actions which belong to Christ as Mediator—just as a man understandeth, but only through his intellect. This must be examined by us: for we say that Christ is Mediator according to both natures, and we place among the effects of the hypostatic union also this, that in the work of mediation each nature had its part, the human always doing what is its own, the divine what is its own.

First Argument: Christ performed the parts of a Mediator before He was incarnate; therefore, He is not Mediator only according to His human nature. The antecedent is proven because, by the consent of all orthodox divines, Christ is that Angel who was honored with divine worship by the patriarchs in the Old Testament. And the name Angel denoteth a messenger, in respect of office, not of person. See examples in Isaiah 63:9, “In all their affliction He was afflicted, and the angel of His presence saved them.” Likewise, in Zechariah 1:12, He intercedeth for Jerusalem, and in chapter 3:2, against Satan for Joshua.

Second Argument: If Christ revealeth to us the doctrine of salvation also as the Son of God, it followeth that He is Mediator as such. The antecedent is true; therefore, the consequent also. The antecedent is proven from John 1:18, “No man hath seen God at any time; the only begotten Son, which is in the bosom of the Father, He hath declared Him.” And in Matthew 11:27, “All things are delivered unto me of my Father: and no man knoweth the Son, but the Father; neither knoweth any man the Father, save the Son, and he to whomsoever the Son will reveal Him.” Hence also, He burneth the hearts and openeth the understanding of His disciples to understand the Scriptures, Luke 24:32, 45; He giveth the Holy Spirit by breathing on them, etc.; hence, He confirmeth His doctrine with divine miracles.

Instance: Bellarmine respondeth that to perform these things efficiently is the work of the whole Trinity; meritoriously, it is the work of the Mediator alone.

Response: Nay, rather, both are the work of the Mediator, because the Mediator is such not only by merit but also by efficacy: whence Christ is said to be made unto us wisdom, etc., “that, according as it is written, He that glorieth, let him glory in the Lord,” 1 Corinthians 1:30-31. This is also shown by the preceding names: Angel, Mediator, etc.

Third Argument: He who emptied Himself is Mediator as He emptied Himself: but the Son of God voluntarily emptied Himself, Philippians 2:7; 2 Corinthians 8:9; John 1:14.

Fourth Argument: In respect of His priestly office, He offered Himself through the eternal Spirit, Hebrews 9:14; He layeth down and taketh again His life, John 2:19; John 10:18; Acts 20:28. He hath an eternal priesthood, Psalm 110:4, “Thou art a priest for ever after the order of Melchizedek,” Hebrews 7:5. In respect of His kingly office, properties purely divine are attributed to Him in His mediatorial function. For He is called God anointed, Psalm 45:7; God who shall reign, Psalm 72:8; Luke 1:33. To Him is attributed efficacy, whereby He can subject all things to Himself, Philippians 3:21; to search hearts. As Mediator, He walketh among the candlesticks, Revelation 2:1. The effects of mediation demonstrate the same, namely, He remitteth sins, justifieth us, sanctifieth us through the Spirit, will raise our bodies, will glorify us, Philippians 3:21.

Objection: 1 Timothy 2:5, “There is one God, and one Mediator between God and men, the man Christ Jesus.”

Response: It doth not say “according to His humanity alone”: the person is denoted, and that nature is noted which is common to Him with all men, to show that we must pray for all. For whenever Christ is called man or the Son of man, His deity is also necessarily denoted as conjoined. But not conversely; for the Son of God was by nature before He was made flesh, and before He was our Redeemer. Elsewhere, it teacheth that God redeemed the Church with His own blood.

Instance: Thus, He would be a Mediator with Himself.

Response: Nor is this absurd. For God in Christ reconciled the world to Himself, 2 Corinthians 5:19. And in Matthew 5:23 and 18:15, we are commanded to be mediators between ourselves and our brethren who have sinned against us. Justice, indeed, is properly toward others, but analogically also toward ourselves. Note here the examples of Roman emperors, who often reconciled rebellious armies and peoples to themselves through their sons, although, if you regard their own right and inheritance, they were not less offended.

Instance: But the offended party cannot be the Mediator.

Response: This is false if taken analogically: otherwise, the person of the Son would not be the Mediator, which is not less offended than the essence, since the essence of the Son is considered in the person of the Son. But properly, according to the economy of our salvation, Christ is the reconciler between us and the Father, and analogically also between Himself and us.

XIV. The Parts of Christ’s Office Are to Be a Prophet, a Priest, and a King.

AMES: The function itself, to which Christ is called, is threefold: that of a Prophet, a Priest, and a King. The number and order of these functions are shown:

  1. By the necessity of men, who labor under ignorance, alienation from God, and inability to return to Him: to which the prophecy of Christ is the remedy for the first, His priesthood for the second, and His kingdom for the third.
  2. By the order of conferring salvation, which must first be expounded, then acquired, and then applied: of which the first is the work of the Prophet, the second of the Priest, and the third of the King.
  3. The same order appeareth from the solemn manner of execution, whereby Christ first taught others, declaring unto them the divine will; then offered Himself; and afterward entered into His kingdom.

XV. For His Prophetic Office, Christ Teacheth the Church the Saving Truth of Religion.

AMES: The prophecy of Christ is that by which He perfectly revealed the whole will of God for salvation: whence He is called in the Scriptures not only a Prophet, Deuteronomy 18:15; Acts 3:22; and a Teacher, Matthew 23:8; the Apostle of our profession, Hebrews 3:1; and the Angel of the covenant, Malachi 3:1; but also the very wisdom of God, 1 Corinthians 1:24; and the treasure of knowledge and understanding, Colossians 2:3. This prophecy was in Christ as in the principal cause: in others, whether angels or men, as in His instruments, 1 Peter 1:11, “Searching what, or what manner of time the Spirit of Christ which was in them did signify, when it testified beforehand the sufferings of Christ, and the glory that should follow.” And 1 Peter 3:19, “By which also He went and preached unto the spirits in prison.” In Christ, it was by way of habit, so that He could, when it pleased Him, reveal all the secrets of God. In others, by way of act and illumination, so that they could not exercise prophecy except at certain times when it pleased Him, as in Jeremiah 42:7.

MACCOVIUS: The prophetic office of Christ is to reveal to us the whole word of God, both externally and internally, where the difference appeareth between men who teach and Christ: for although men teach, they do so only externally, not internally, and thus they labor in vain when they encounter a dull and unteachable mind. For doctrine proposed externally instructeth a keen and attentive mind, but doth not make it keen and attentive. Our condition is different, who by nature are dull, and in heavenly things blinder than moles. Therefore, we needed the supreme Teacher, who could dispel this blindness of the mind. For it is enough for one who is not blind to see a torch held before him: but for the blind, it is not enough even to be struck by the whole sun. Therefore, as we have said, there are two parts of the prophetic office: the external promulgation of divine truth, and the internal illumination of hearts by the Holy Spirit.

  • The external promulgation of divine truth is the first part of Christ’s office, when He preached the Gospel of God’s grace and the redemption of mankind, interpreted the law, and foretold future things. Therefore, its parts are two: doctrine and the prediction of future things.
  • The parts of doctrine, in turn, are two: the revelation of the Gospel and the true interpretation of the law.
    • The revelation of the Gospel is the first part of Christ’s doctrine, when He preached the kingdom of grace and repentance, and revealed the secret counsel and all the will of the Father concerning our reconciliation with Him, Genesis 5:15; Matthew 4:17; John 1:18; John 15:15; Matthew 11:27.
    • The true interpretation of the law is the other part of Christ’s doctrine, when He expounded the true meaning of the divine law according to the mind of the lawgiver God Himself, to free it from the corruptions of the Pharisees, Matthew 5:20 and following.
  • The prediction of future things is to be attributed to Christ, both in the Old and New Testaments, 1 Peter 1:11; Acts 3:19-20; Revelation 22:16.
  • The internal illumination of hearts by the Holy Spirit is the other and chief part of Christ’s prophetic office, when through the Holy Spirit He moveth the faithful to understand with their minds and desire with their hearts the things that are taught, and to rest in them, Luke 24:32, 45; Acts 16:14. Hence, for these effects flowing from this office, Christ is called not only a Prophet but also a Counselor, Teacher, etc. Moreover, since we acknowledge Christ as the only Teacher, and indeed the internal one, it is necessary to confess that He is God, who inscribeth His law not on tables of stone but on tables of flesh, so that with Job 39:22 we may exclaim: “Who is a teacher like unto Him?”

XVI. But He Did Not Add to the Moral Law with New or More Perfect Precepts.

PROFESSOR: For it is false that Christ added anything to the law of Moses to make it perfect from imperfect: since the law, when first given by God, was always the most perfect rule of good works, for nothing more perfect can be required than the love of God with all the heart, which requireth the integrity of the whole nature and the conformity of all thoughts, words, and actions with the norm of justice. Hence, Christ referreth those who seek life by works to the law, Matthew 19:17; Luke 10:28. But if the law, when fulfilled, hath the efficacy to confer eternal life, nothing can be added to its perfection. And Bellarmine himself, forgetting his own position, rightly noteth that Christ in Matthew 5 did not say, “Except your righteousness shall exceed that of the prophets,” but “that of the scribes and Pharisees,” to signify that He did not wish to add to the burdens of the King’s precepts, but to remove the corruptions of the scribes and Pharisees, De Justificatione, book 4, chapter 4. But what is found in Matthew 5, John 13, and elsewhere are not new commands of the Gospel, properly so called, added to the precepts of the moral law, and more exact than they, but are the same which Moses delivered to the people of God, repeated by Christ, purged from Pharisaic corruptions, and restored to their original luster by genuine interpretation. Therefore, the Scholastics and Jesuits err when they assert that a new law was given by Christ, and that its precepts are far more perfect, excellent, and severe than those of Moses. Lombard, Sentences, book 3, distinction 4; Thomas Aquinas, on Matthew 5 and Summa Theologica, 1.2. q.91, art.5; Scotus, Sentences, book 3, distinction 4; Biel, Sentences, book 3, distinction 4; Bellarmine, De Justificatione, book 4, chapters 3 and 4. The Socinians also err, who establish two kinds of Christ’s commands, some added by Him to each precept of the Decalogue, others delivered by Him separately to the Apostles.

MACCOVIUS: In the Gospel, there are no good works distinct from the law formally. The adversaries, when pressed that a man is not justified by the works of the law, admit this, and say that it is so, but that nevertheless, a man is not justified by the works of the Gospel. Hence, they distinguish between the works of the law and of the Gospel. But if this distinction holdeth, then there will also be sins committed against the doctrine of the Gospel. Therefore, the definition of sin given by the Holy Spirit in 1 John 3:4, that sin is the transgression of the law, will not be adequate. What, then, will be the general definition of sin? Certainly, the adversaries must provide it, if this definition given by the Holy Spirit is only of sin committed against the law. But the Gospel is distinguished from the law; meanwhile, the doctrine of the Gospel is commanded by the law. For God requireth that we believe the Gospel; therefore, we are bound to believe it. But how? Because we ought to love God with all our heart, etc., and therefore to obey Him in all that He commandeth. But this is the reason of the law: therefore, insofar as obedience is rendered to the Gospel, it is from the law, and in this way, the good work of the Gospel doth not differ formally from the law; but insofar as the law doth not teach this doctrine, but only commandeth obedience to it, since this doctrine is distinct from the law, the works of the Gospel differ from those of the law materially.

XVII. Christ’s Priestly Office Consisteth in That He Offered Himself to God as a True Expiation for Sins, and Continually Intercedeth for Us Before the Father.

AMES: The priesthood of Christ is that by which He expiated the sins of men and reconciled them to the favor of God, Colossians 1:20. This priesthood was not legal or temporary, but after the order of Melchizedek, Hebrews 7:17; not from a carnal commandment, but from the power of an indissoluble life, verse 16; not of a weak and imperfect order, but stable and perfect, verses 18-19; not for a time, but eternal, verse 24; admitting no successor or vicar, but perpetual and proper to Christ, as He ever liveth, verses 24-25. In this office, Christ Himself was the priest, the sacrifice, and the altar. He was the priest according to both natures, Hebrews 5:6. The sacrifice was most properly according to His human nature. Whence in the Scriptures, this is attributed not only to the person of Christ but to His body, Hebrews 10:10; 1 Peter 2:24; Colossians 1:22; to His blood, Colossians 1:20; and to His soul, Isaiah 53:10; Matthew 20:28. Yet the chief power by which this sacrifice was made effectual depended on His divine nature: because the Son of God offered Himself for us, Acts 20:28; Romans 8:3. The altar was properly according to His divine nature, Hebrews 9:14; 13:10, 12, 15; for it is the function of the altar to sanctify the offering, and therefore it must be of greater dignity than the sacrifice itself, Matthew 23:17. Christ, through His divine nature, sanctified Himself in some way according to His human nature, John 17:19. Hence, it also appeareth how necessary it was that Christ the Mediator should be both God and man: for if He were not man, He would not have been a suitable sacrifice; and if He were not God, the sacrifice would not have been of sufficient virtue.

XVIII. By True Satisfaction, Christ Expiated Our Sins.

MACCOVIUS: The satisfaction of Christ is that by which He satisfied for our sins in our stead, by enduring what we owed according to the justice of God.

WAL: Socinus, to whom Vorstius partly consenteth, against the consensus of the whole Christian Church, both ancient and modern, first dared to teach in his book De Servatore and elsewhere, that sins are forgiven us without any satisfaction by Christ intervening, indeed, that the divine justice could not be satisfied by Christ’s obedience, nor did it require such satisfaction. But that Christ is our Mediator only insofar as He revealed to us a new way to eternal life and sealed it with His death. The arguments brought against Socinus are many and varied, which we shall reduce to certain classes.

First Argument: We take it from those places where Christ is said to have redeemed us, also to have bought us, lutroun, apolutroun, apolutrothai, also agorazein and exagorazein, which are very numerous. See only these few: Romans 3:24, “Being justified freely by His grace through the redemption that is in Christ Jesus.” Titus 2:14, “Who gave Himself for us, that He might redeem us from all iniquity.” Hebrews 9:12, “Having obtained eternal redemption.” So apolutrosis, Romans 3:24; Colossians 1:14; Ephesians 1:7, “In whom we have redemption through His blood.” Likewise, agorazein and exagorazein, 1 Corinthians 6:20, “Ye are bought with a price.” Revelation 5:9, “Thou wast slain, and hast redeemed us to God by thy blood.” So Galatians 3:13, “Christ hath redeemed us from the curse of the law,” and 4:4. From which places we argue thus: In every redemption and purchase, there is a true price and satisfaction. We were redeemed by Christ, and He is our Redeemer: therefore, etc.

Instance: But the word of buying and redeeming is frequently used for mere deliverance, in which no satisfaction interveneth: therefore, it is not necessary here. They prove the antecedent from those places where God is said to have redeemed His people from Egypt, Exodus 15:13; Deuteronomy 7:8; 9:26; 2 Samuel 7:23; Nehemiah 1:10; and Acts 7:35, where Moses is called a redeemer.

Response: I grant that in Holy Scripture, the word “redeem” is sometimes used metaphorically for “deliver” in any way: just as one who is bought is delivered from the power of another and passeth into the power of the buyer; but it doth not follow from this that our redemption through Christ is only metaphorical; because the justice of God in spiritual redemption requireth another mode of redemption, and the type and the thing signified by the type do not always agree in all respects: for there is something more in this than in that. But to the point: let them prove that Scripture speaketh of external and corporeal redemption, and of deliverance through Moses, in the same way as it speaketh of Christ. I. It saith that Christ gave Himself and His life as lutron and antilutron, Matthew 20:28; 1 Timothy 2:6. II. It saith that we are bought, and indeed with a price; also bought with blood, also bought and redeemed through blood. III. The manner in which we are bought is often added. Galatians 3:13, “redeemed us from the curse, being made a curse for us”; also, “made sin for us, that we might be made the righteousness of God in Him,” 2 Corinthians 5:21; and 1 Peter 1:18, “Redeemed from your vain conversation, not with silver and gold, but with the precious blood.” Let them show such manners of speaking in metaphorical redemption.

Second Argument: It is taken from places where Christ is said to have propitiated or reconciled us to God, or with God, through His death and obedience. Romans 3:25, “Whom God hath set forth to be a propitiation through faith in His blood.” Romans 5:10, “For if, when we were enemies, we were reconciled to God by the death of His Son.” 2 Corinthians 5:18, “And all things are of God, who hath reconciled us to Himself by Jesus Christ.” 1 John 2:2, “And He is the propitiation for our sins.” And Ephesians 2:16; Colossians 2:14, “Blotting out the handwriting of ordinances that was against us.”

Exception: They deny that in these places it is said that God is reconciled to us, but say that it is said that we are reconciled to God through Christ. But this is frivolous, because if we are reconciled to God, it necessarily followeth that God is reconciled to us; since in this reconciliation, God is presupposed as angry with our sins, to whom we are reconciled; and Paul in Romans 5:9 saith that we are delivered through Christ from wrath; certainly, no wrath but that of God the judge can be understood here. Then, the word hilasmos and hilasis can only be understood of the propitiation of God: for we do not propitiate God, but God propitiateth us.

Third Argument: Christ is the Mediator between God and men, not only in respect of doctrine, as a Prophet, or of the administration of the means of salvation and efficacy, as a King, but also as a Priest; therefore, He is a Mediator as a satisfier for us and our propitiator.

Instance: But to Christ as Priest, it peculiarly belongeth that He intercedeth for us in heaven.

Response: I. It is true that this is also a priestly action of Christ; but it is false that it is the only one. For Christ was a priest while on earth, and as a Priest, He offered Himself on the cross. The words of Scripture are clear and plain. Hebrews 7:26-27, “For such an high priest became us, who is holy, harmless, undefiled, separate from sinners, and made higher than the heavens; who needeth not daily, as those high priests, to offer up sacrifice, first for his own sins, and then for the people’s: for this He did once, when He offered up Himself.” And Hebrews 9:14, “How much more shall the blood of Christ, who through the eternal Spirit offered Himself without spot to God, purge your conscience from dead works to serve the living God?” The intercession in heaven is the perpetual commemoration of this unique sacrifice, Romans 8:34. But the sacrifice of Christ was performed once, and by one offering He hath perfected for ever them that are sanctified, Hebrews 10:12. II. Otherwise, Scripture speaketh of Christ’s priestly mediation, as in Hebrews 9:15, “And for this cause He is the Mediator of the new testament,” and 1 Timothy 2:5. Therefore, not only as Prophet or as King is He Mediator, but as Priest, offering Himself on earth and paying the price of redemption for past sins.

Fourth Argument: If through the death of Christ the sins of those who lived before the coming of Christ in the flesh were expiated and abolished, then the death of Christ necessarily hath the character of merit and of a cause moving God to forgive sins, because no other reason can be devised, nor is adduced by Socinus himself, by which this could be done. The antecedent is certain; therefore, the consequent also. I prove the antecedent from these two places: Hebrews 9:15, “And for this cause He is the Mediator of the new testament, that by means of death, for the redemption of the transgressions that were under the first testament, they which are called might receive the promise of eternal inheritance.” Where the phrase apolutrosis ton parabason admitteth no other kind of cause, nor can the death of Christ, in respect of preceding sins, deliver men from sins except as a moving cause: whence also He is called by John in Revelation 13:8, “the Lamb slain from the foundation of the world.” The other place is Hebrews 9:26, where the Apostle proveth that Christ offered Himself once, not often, as the high priest of the Old Testament often sacrificed; because otherwise He must have suffered often since the foundation of the world. This would be no reason of the Apostle if the unique sacrifice of Christ did not have the power to expiate sins even under the Old Testament, as is clearly asserted in Acts 13:32 and 15:10, “Now therefore why tempt ye God, to put a yoke upon the neck of the disciples, which neither our fathers nor we were able to bear?”

Fifth Argument: The Holy Scripture in many places testifieth that Christ died for us. Therefore, He died to expiate sins and in our place. Socinus denieth the consequent, because He can be said to have died for us, even if not in our place; but only to seal His doctrine and to pave the way for Himself to enter into glory, in which He intercedeth for us and governeth us.

Response: That this exception is false is proven by the following invincible reasons:

  1. Because the Apostle considereth it blasphemy to say that another was crucified for us besides Christ, 1 Corinthians 1:13. Likewise, 2 Timothy 2:5. But in respect of sealing and example, Paul himself and other Apostles suffered for the Church, Colossians 1:24, “Who now rejoice in my sufferings for you.”
  2. Although the word huper can sometimes be taken simply for any benefit, yet the word anti, which Scripture frequently useth in this matter, always signifieth substitution and vicariousness, nor can any contrary example be given or adduced by Socinus. As Grotius himself rightly observeth here. Thus, kakon anti kakou, 1 Peter 3:9; ophthalmos anti ophthalmou, odon anti odontos, Matthew 5:38; Hebrews 12:16, ta prototokia anti broseos mias, in which substitution and compensation are clearly understood. Now, Scripture frequently speaketh of Christ giving Himself for us in this way. As in Matthew 20:28, lutron anti pollon, and Mark 10:45, and likewise antilutronelsewhere.
  3. There are manifest places in which that compensation is clearly noted, as in John 11:50, “It is expedient for us, that one man should die for the people, and that the whole nation perish not,” which is explained in the following concerning Christ. Romans 5:6, “For when we were yet without strength, in due time Christ died for the ungodly. For scarcely for a righteous man will one die: yet peradventure for a good man some would even dare to die.” Where substitution is clearly understood. For otherwise, many die for their country, king, and flock, that is, for their benefit; but that one should undergo another’s punishment in his place, few do. So in 2 Corinthians 5:14, “For the love of Christ constraineth us; because we thus judge, that if one died for all, then were all dead.” There is no consequence here unless “died for all” meaneth died in the place or stead of all.

Sixth Argument: From those places in which Christ is said to have borne our sins, or taken them upon Himself, or to have been made sin or a curse for us, Isaiah 53:4; Galatians 3:13; 2 Corinthians 5:21, etc. In which places, substitution is manifestly denoted.

Instance: But “to bear” here everywhere meaneth “to take away.”

Response: It is true that Christ, by bearing, also took away; but clearly, this bearing or imputation precedeth the taking away, as in Isaiah 53:11, “He shall see of the travail of His soul, and shall be satisfied: by His knowledge shall my righteous servant justify many; for He shall bear their iniquities.” The word nasasignifieth “to sustain,” not “to take away”: when joined with sin, it meaneth “to bear the punishment for sin.” Nor is the place in Jeremiah, “Our fathers have sinned, and we bear their iniquities,” to be understood otherwise than that they murmured against God, that they were punished for the sins of their parents, as in Ezekiel 18:19; and truly, those who imitate the sins of their parents make themselves guilty of them, Exodus 20:5. So in 1 Peter 2:24, “Who His own self bare our sins in His own body on the tree.” Nor is the word anapherein ever taken simply for “to take away.” For the place in Hebrews 9:28, “So Christ was once offered to bear the sins of many; and unto them that look for Him shall He appear the second time without sin unto salvation,” which he adduceth in his favor, is against him, because He appeared first with sin imputed, then without sin in glory. And in Isaiah 53:6-7, “All we like sheep have gone astray; we have turned every one to his own way; and the Lord hath laid on Him the iniquity of us all. He was oppressed, and He was afflicted.” Nor can the word hiphgia signify “God met through Him the iniquities of us all,” as Socinus wisheth. Because the Hebrew word signifieth a double action, “caused to meet.” “The chastisement of our peace was upon Him; and with His stripes we are healed.”

Seventh Argument: Finally, from the nature of the propitiatory sacrifice. For Christ offered Himself as a victim, Ephesians 5:2, and frequently He is called the Lamb slain, Revelation 5:12. Socinus respondeth that Christ is indeed called a victim and sacrifice, but it is not said therefore that He is a truly propitiatory and satisfactory victim for sins; but by a certain metaphor, just as the death of martyrs is also called an offering and victim, because it hath some agreement with victims. But this is invincibly refuted from the ancient types themselves. For:

  1. That the victims of the Old Testament were satisfactory is proven from many places where victims are said to expiate sins, and are called sins themselves. Two places will suffice: Leviticus 17:11, “For the life of the flesh is in the blood: and I have given it to you upon the altar to make an atonement for your souls: for it is the blood that maketh an atonement for the soul.” And Leviticus 16:9, where two goats are appointed, one for a sacrifice, “And Aaron shall bring the goat upon which the Lord’s lot fell, and offer him for a sin offering.” The other is the scapegoat, upon which the sins of the people were laid.
  2. The law is expressly said to have had a shadow of good things to come, Hebrews 10:1; and in 9:9, they are called figures, patterns, antitypes, verse 23, 24; so in Colossians 2:17. This is proven by the interchange of names, which occurreth in types, not in simple metaphors. Thus, Christ is called the Lamb, John 1:29, and conversely, Christ is called our Passover, 1 Corinthians 5:7.
  3. That Christ’s sacrifice was truly expiatory, signified by those ancient ones, is proven because He is called the Lamb who taketh away the sins of the world, John 1:29; and most clearly in Hebrews 9:13-14, “For if the blood of bulls and of goats, and the ashes of an heifer sprinkling the unclean, sanctifieth to the purifying of the flesh: how much more shall the blood of Christ, who through the eternal Spirit offered Himself without spot to God, purge your conscience from dead works to serve the living God?” And verse 23, “It was therefore necessary that the patterns of things in the heavens should be purified with these; but the heavenly things themselves with better sacrifices than these,” that is, with Christ’s.

Instance: But these are attributed to Christ metaphorically.

Response: This is false: for to shadows correspond not metaphors, but the truth, and to shadows is opposed the truth, John 1:17, “For the law was given by Moses, but grace and truth came by Jesus Christ.” Colossians 2:17, “Which are a shadow of things to come; but the body is of Christ.” Therefore, the truth and the body are opposed to types, not metaphors. Second, Christ would then be only a metaphorical priest: but He is a true priest, and indeed after the order of Melchizedek, more excellent than Aaron. Third, the purging of sins would then be only metaphorical, if the victim were metaphorical. But it is a true expiation, Hebrews 12:24, “And to Jesus the Mediator of the new covenant, and to the blood of sprinkling, that speaketh better things than that of Abel.” Therefore, not only martyrdom, but expiation is caused.

XIX. Christ Suffered for Us Both Bodily and Spiritual Pains, Even the Gravest Punishments in His Soul.

WAL: It now followeth that against the Papists and Bellarmine, we prove that Christ, to satisfy for our sins, sustained not only temporal or bodily death but also spiritual and eternal death in His soul for us, not indeed in duration, but in equivalence and essence or nature. To understand this, it must be known that there is a double death of man: one by which the soul is separated from the body, the other relational, namely, by which the soul is separated from the sense of divine favor and, on the contrary, apprehendeth and feeleth the infinite wrath of God against sins. Thus David, Psalm 18:5 and 116:3, “The sorrows of hell compassed me about.” Romans 2:9, “Tribulation and anguish, upon every soul of man that doeth evil.” Since sin meriteth infinite punishment, and a mere creature cannot bear it infinitely in intensity, hence it beareth it successively and in eternal duration, unless delivered by the grace of Christ. But Christ, who is not only man but also God, bore an immense punishment, infinite in virtue and intensity; and therefore, by the power of His divinity and the dignity of His merit, He emerged from it and delivered Himself first, and us with Him, from it.

First Argument: For demonstrating this, it is taken from places where Christ is asserted to have borne all the punishment due to our sins. As in Isaiah 53:6, “The Lord hath laid on Him the iniquity of us all.” Verse 7, “He was oppressed, and He was afflicted.” Verse 12, “He bare the sin of many.” 2 Corinthians 5:21; Colossians 2:14; 1 Peter 2:24. These places speak not of some part of sins and punishments but of all, among which the chief are the spiritual punishments of the soul, Romans 2:9; therefore, etc.

Second Argument: From Galatians 3:13, “Christ hath redeemed us from the curse of the law, being made a curse for us.” But the curse doth not signify only the death of the body but chiefly that relational one of the soul. Therefore, etc.

Third Argument: From the anguish and sorrow of Christ in the garden, and His complaint on the cross, “My God, my God, why hast thou forsaken me?” Here Christ shuddered in the garden at the punishment which He sustained on the cross and exhausted when He said, “It is finished”: for He overcame it by the power of His divinity and the constancy of His faith.

Fourth Argument: From the type of Christ, David, who several times testified that he was conflicted with the sorrows of hell, as in Psalm 18:5; 116:3; and 16:10, “For thou wilt not leave my soul in hell; neither wilt thou suffer thine Holy One to see corruption,” which God raised up, having loosed the pains of hell, namely, those which awaited us. Some interpret this of the pains of the grave, which is inappropriate because there are no pains of the grave, much less the greatest ones, such as David describeth here.

Fifth Argument: This was required for our salvation, because Christ was the Redeemer not only of bodies but especially of souls.

XX. And Thus He Satisfied the Law with the Fullest Righteousness, Both Active and Passive.

GOMARUS: Christ, by His entire humiliation and voluntary submission, both in action and in passion, satisfied for us: for both action, Deuteronomy 6:25; Leviticus 18:5; Romans 2:13, and passion, Deuteronomy 27:26, the law required from us, since we were created in the image of God and are debtors; which, being twofold, namely, the retribution for lawlessness through sufficient punishment to satisfy the violation of the law and the anathema of the curse (which we call passive justice), and the fulfillment of universal and perfect lawfulness, of nature and life, according to the demand of the law (which is called active justice), therefore, the merit of Christ must contain these two integral parts, not distinct in time but in nature, Matthew 3:15; Romans 5:19; Galatians 4:4; Philippians 2:8; Hebrews 7:26. Otherwise, according to the law (which here, as a strict and rigid mistress, must be observed), we would still be either guilty of condemnation or not yet heirs of life. Therefore, the Prophet rightly connecteth both: the expiation of iniquity and the bringing in of everlasting righteousness, Daniel 9:24. These two acts must not be separated but distinguished: for there can be innocence and incomplete justice, at least in respect of duration, between them, as was in the first humans before the fall, who were neither guilty of death nor yet had a right to life.

WAL:

First Reason: That obedience was necessary to satisfy God’s justice, to which the promise of life is made: but the promise of life is made only to active obedience, “Do this and live”: therefore, etc. The major is self-evident: for to satisfy is to do what God required for life.

Second Reason: Satisfaction of justice required that what we owed should be fulfilled by our sponsor: but we owed not only punishment for sin but also obedience for guilt. Therefore, etc.

Third Reason: Christ satisfied for us in the manner prefigured in the Old Testament, so that satisfaction might be made. But in the Old Testament, not only passive but also active obedience was prefigured. Therefore, etc.

The minor is proven: Because in the typical priest, purity was required, in garments and washings; in the sacrifice, integrity, which integrity was offered with the sacrifice and in the sacrifice as part of it; then, incense was also offered, which did not figure passion but the actions and prayers of the high priest.

Fourth Reason: From the place in Romans 5:19, “For as by one man’s disobedience many were made sinners, so by the obedience of one shall many be made righteous.”

Instance: But by obedience is understood only the obedience which He rendered in death.

Response:

  1. Even if we granted this, it would still follow that there is active obedience.
  2. It is denied that only that is understood: because it is opposed to Adam’s disobedience, which was against the whole law. Then, because in verse 18 it is said, “Therefore as by the offence of one judgment came upon all men to condemnation; even so by the righteousness of one the free gift came upon all men unto justification of life.” But righteousness cannot be called only passion, nor can the whole passion of Christ be called righteousness. Nor should the meaning of the word obedience be restricted without necessity. Compare the place in Philippians 2:8, where it is said that Christ humbled Himself and became obedient unto death, even the death of the cross. In which place, obedience can be taken not only for obedience to a single command, namely, to undergo death, but also for all obedience preceding death, because it saith that Christ became obedient unto death, even the death of the cross. Which manner of speaking includeth the whole obedience which Christ rendered to the Father.

Fifth Reason: From the place in Romans 10:4, “For Christ is the end of the law for righteousness to every one that believeth.” Whence I argue thus: If Christ is the end or perfection of the law for righteousness, then it necessarily followeth that we find in Christ that righteousness which the law requireth, as He clearly speaketh in Romans 8:3-4, “For what the law could not do, in that it was weak through the flesh, God sending His own Son in the likeness of sinful flesh, and for sin, condemned sin in the flesh: that the righteousness of the law might be fulfilled in us.” If He condemned or abolished sin, that the righteousness of the law might be fulfilled in us, then certainly that righteousness which the law contained and could not communicate must be found in Christ by us: but the law contained active righteousness, and the righteousness of the law is, “Do this, and thou shalt live”: therefore, etc.

Sixth Reason: From the place in Galatians 4:4, from which I argue thus: Christ satisfied for us in that by which He redeemed us from the law and obtained for us the adoption of sons: but the obedience to the law did this, as it is in the text: therefore, etc. And in Hebrews 10:5, compare with Psalm 40:6-8, “Sacrifice and offering thou didst not desire; mine ears hast thou opened: burnt offering and sin offering hast thou not required. Then said I, Lo, I come: in the volume of the book it is written of me, I delight to do thy will, O my God: yea, thy law is within my heart.”

XXI. And Thus He Merited Salvation for Us from God.

ZANCHIUS: We believe that Christ, by His perfect obedience, merited eternal life not only for Himself but also for us: by His passion and death, He expiated our sins in His flesh: He redeemed us from the hands of Satan and from the tyranny of death and the servitude of sin: He reconciled us to God in Himself and made us dear, that we might be accounted righteous in Him before God the Father: and by His resurrection and ascension into heaven, He obtained for us both resurrections, namely, the first and the second (as John speaketh in Revelation 20:5), and took possession of the heavenly inheritance in our name also.

GOMARUS: Properly, merit can be predicated of Jesus Christ as man, since, according to the hypothesis of the law and the divine covenant, and by the full performance of His mediatorial office, without any omission of the required condition, He rendered what He was bound to render for our redemption. The merit of Christ is the entire and absolute obedience of the Son of the Most High God, by which, sent by the Father to the office of Mediator into this world, He willingly subjected Himself to His will, Hebrews 10:7, 9; John 10:17; Galatians 1:4; Ephesians 5:2, 25; even unto death, Philippians 2:8; and to the curse, Galatians 3:13; perfectly fulfilling the law, Matthew 3:15; 5:17; Galatians 4:4; and fully satisfying the judgment of God, John 19:30; that He might deliver us from both the first and the second curse, Galatians 3:13; Hosea 13:14; 1 Corinthians 15:54; Hebrews 2:14; and acquire for us the reward of eternal life, John 10:28; 17:2; Hebrews 5:9.

AMES: In the same humiliation of Christ, there was also merit, insofar as it is ordered to our benefit, or to acquire for us some good under the aspect of reward. This is shown by all those places of Scripture which say that by His obedience He procured for us righteousness, Romans 5:19; the favor of God, Romans 5:10, “We were reconciled to God by the death of His Son”; and eternal life, Romans 6:23, “The gift of God is eternal life through Jesus Christ our Lord.” The merit and satisfaction of Christ do not differ in reality, as if they were to be sought in various and distinct operations: but they are to be acknowledged in one and the same obedience under different aspects.

VOETIUS: Merit, in Greek axia, is a middle term, and signifieth both the dignity of punishment and of reward, as the Scholastics note; the dignity of punishment they call demerit with a special word. Merit is a work performed, to which, according to distributive justice, a reward or retribution proportional to the work is due. Among the Scholastics, Thomas, in Summa Theologica, part 3, question 49, article 6, defineth it as an action by which it is just that something be given to the agent, etc. The merit of Christ is the most perfect obedience, by which He, in our place as our sponsor, fully satisfied the justice of the divine law, and acquired for us the remission of sins and absolution or freedom from the curse, and together righteousness, and the right and possession of eternal life. Further, since merit is relative and hath respect to punishment or to reward, and that by debt or according to justice, Romans 1:32; Hebrews 10:29; Romans 4:4, there are to be considered distinctly in the merit of Christ the meritorious work and the reward. The meritorious work of Christ is that voluntary and most perfect obedience, by which in His human nature, in our place and for us as our sponsor, He rendered all that the law of God required of us, Romans 5:19; 8:3. For the law of God required of us sinners first, condign punishments both of soul and body: see this proven in the Elements of Catechetics, questions 9 and 11. Then, the most perfect holiness and the most exact conformity with the law of God, if we would enter into life, Leviticus 18:5 with Galatians 3:12; Matthew 19:17, which see more fully explained and proven at Catechism question 62. But Christ, as Mediator and sponsor, rendered both in our place: bearing all the punishments due to the saved for all their sins, not indeed in kind, but as to compensation and equivalence; and fulfilling all the righteousness of the law and conformity most exactly to the least jot, both in habit and in act, without any species of sin or defect, either habitual or actual, Isaiah 53:9; 2 Corinthians 5:21; Hebrews 7:26. The reward acquired by Christ through this work is twofold: first, freedom or immunity from the servitude or power of sin, both damning and reigning, for the saved alone, not for Christ. Then, the right, possession, and enjoyment of eternal life, both for Christ as that particular man and as the head of the saved, and for all the saved as His members.

XXII. Christ Performed These Things for His Elect and Those to Be Saved, Only and All, Who Have Lived, or Will Live.

GOMARUS: The end to which these benefits of Christ’s death are divinely destined is all and only the elect. All, because they are common to each of them: only, because they are proper to them, not to the reprobate. Whence, for the first reason, sometimes, due to the excellence of dignity, the universality of the elect (when the end and fruit of Christ’s death are treated) is called all, 2 Corinthians 5:15; Hebrews 2:9; all things, 2 Corinthians 5:17-18; the world, John 1:29; 3:17; 4:42; 6:51; 17:21, 23; the whole world, 1 John 2:2, namely, of the elect; and distinctly from the Jews, the assembly of the elect Gentiles is called the world, Romans 11:12, 15. Conversely, the multitude of the reprobate, due to the excellence of number, is called the world, John 14:17; 17:9; the world of the ungodly, 2 Peter 2:5; the whole world, 1 John 5:19, by a synecdoche. So that the entire world, Romans 3:19, according to the usage of Scripture, is distributed into these two particular worlds, lest we rashly stumble upon the word “world.” For the second reason, they are distinctly called not all, but many. For although, due to the infinite dignity of Christ’s person, the price of His death is of infinite value (so that it would abundantly suffice even for a thousand worlds to be saved, if they believed), nevertheless, that the Savior died not for all, even the reprobate, but for the elect alone, is demonstrated by this distinction of many from the rest, and by other invincible reasons in the sacred letters. To this pertain these illustrious sentences: “By His knowledge shall my righteous servant justify many; for He shall bear their iniquities,” Isaiah 53:11. “He bare the sin of many,” verse 12. “To give His life a ransom for many,” Matthew 20:28. “This is my blood of the new testament, which is shed for many,” Matthew 26:28, etc. The same is shown by the confession of the heavenly Church, when, distinctly extolling this privilege of Christ’s death for the elect, it saith, “Thou wast slain, and hast redeemed us to God by thy blood out of every kindred, and tongue, and people, and nation,” Revelation 5:9. Therefore, not all and every one of the nations, but the elect many out of them, verses 7 and 8, are redeemed by Christ’s death, who alone have washed their robes and made them white in the blood of the Lamb, verse 14. Nor doth Scripture teach otherwise, when it saith that Christ laid down His life for His sheep and His own, John 10:15, 12 (that is, for the elect, verses 16, 28, 29, of whom alone He is the shepherd, not of the goats, not of the wolves, verses 26, 27); “gave Himself for the Church,” Ephesians 5:25; “for us,” Isaiah 53:6; Ephesians 5:2, the faithful; “for them that are sanctified,” Hebrews 10:14; “for them that are called,” Hebrews 9:15.
