Who alone are His people, and of whom alone He is the Savior: as the proper definition of the name Jesus demonstrateth: “Thou shalt call His name Jesus: for He shall save His people from their sins,” Matthew 1:21. It was prophesied that Jesus should die for that nation; and not for that nation only, but that also He should gather together in one the children of God that were scattered abroad, John 11:51-52. Whence He ought in all things to be made like unto His brethren, that He might be a merciful and faithful high priest in things pertaining to God, to make reconciliation for the sins of the people, Hebrews 2:17. To this are added other demonstrations, drawn from the causes (efficient and final, and from the fruit), which belong to the elect alone, not to the reprobate. And first, indeed, from the primary and moving efficient cause, which is twofold: the vindicating justice of God and His preserving love. From the justice of God: which can neither leave the guilty unpunished nor exact deserved punishments twice (from the guilty and from the sponsor simultaneously). I. For whoever alone are entirely freed from the punishment due for their sins, for them alone Christ paid the punishment of death: but the elect to salvation alone are entirely freed from the punishment due for their sins: therefore, for them alone Christ paid the punishment of death. II. Whoever pay the punishment due for their sins by eternal torment themselves, for them Christ did not satisfy by the price of His death: but all the reprobate pay the punishment due for their sins by eternal torment themselves: therefore, Christ did not satisfy for them by the price of His death.

MACCOVIUS: Salvation is obtained by the merit of Christ as by a moral cause. But the nature of this kind of cause is such that it hath force even when it is not yet in act, provided it is known to be, as they say in the Schools. Examples of this are very many in life, for there would be no society, no commerce among men, if promises had no effect until they are fulfilled. Therefore, since with God (to whom all things are present) Christ’s merit was most certain, even though it was future, yet it already exerted its power. The same is the case with an exemplary cause, for it is not necessary that the exemplar be actually in existence to be an exemplar; it is enough that it be in the mind.

XXIII. And for the Same, Christ Continually Intercedeth Before the Father.

MACCOVIUS: The other act of the priesthood is the intercession of Christ, by which He is an advocate and intercessor with God for the faithful. The intercession of Christ is immediately referred to the Father, 1 John 2:1, “If any man sin, we have an advocate with the Father, Jesus Christ the righteous.” And indeed, the Father, as He is first in order, so when the Father is placated, the Son and the Holy Spirit are also placated, because there is one consenting will of all the persons. Moreover, as Christ alone is our Mediator, so He alone intercedeth for us, and hath interceded since the Gospel was revealed. For no one is worthy to present himself to God and to come into His sight, through whom God may be invoked, except Christ alone. Therefore, the Papists are foolish when they teach that we go to God through the saints, as through courtiers and counselors to a king and prince.

Whether this appearance of Christ for us is that sacrifice which Christ is said to have offered for us is inquired: Socinus affirmeth it. The Orthodox deny it. We have shown above that, as the legal sacrifices were performed before entering the holy of holies, and the blood from the performed sacrifice was accustomed to be taken and brought into the holy of holies, so now it is done by Christ, who in heaven representeth and offereth to God the sacrifice performed by Himself for the expiation of sins: which when He doth, He in a way claimeth His right, that by the sacrifice performed by Himself, the sins of men may be expiated and they may be actually admitted to that remission of sins which He prepared for them on the cross. Therefore, a double oblation is to be distinguished here: one which is in the sacrifice, and which is essential to the sacrifice, as when Abraham offered his son to death, willing to slay him: the other is subsequent to the sacrifice, namely, when the sacrifice already made is represented to God, to this end, that it may be acceptable and pleasing to God for all those effects which depend on that sacrifice to be granted. The former oblation was on the cross, the latter is in heaven.

XXIV. Christ Showeth Himself a King in Gathering, Preserving, and Promoting the Church, That Is, His Spiritual Kingdom.

AMES: The kingdom of Christ is that by which He dispenseth and administereth with authority or power all things that pertain to the salvation of men, Psalm 2:6; Daniel 2:44; Luke 1:33. The properties of this kingdom are:

  1. That it is universal:
    • In respect of all ages, Matthew 22:43.
    • In respect of every kind of men, Daniel 7:14.
    • In respect of all creatures also, insofar as they in any way pertain to promoting or illustrating the salvation of men, Ephesians 1:22.
  2. That it is over the very souls and consciences of men, Romans 14:17.
  3. That it dispenseth eternal life and death, Revelation 1:18.
  4. That it is eternal, Daniel 2:44; 7:14.
  5. That it bringeth supreme peace and perfect happiness to those who are its heirs, Isaiah 9:6; Ephesians 2:16. Hence, this kingdom is called in the Scriptures the kingdom of God, passim; the kingdom of peace and glory; the kingdom of light and glory; the kingdom of heaven; and the world to come, Hebrews 2:5. And hence it also appeareth how necessary it was that Christ the Mediator should be both God and man: for if He were not God, He could not be the spiritual king of our souls, dispensing eternal life and death; and if He were not man, He could not be the head of the same kind with the body.

MACCOVIUS: It is called the kingdom of heaven for various reasons:

  1. Because the King who possesseth this kingdom is not earthly from the earth, but heavenly from heaven, whether we consider His eternity according to His divine nature or His origin according to His human nature, for He was born according to His human nature in a wholly heavenly manner through the Holy Spirit.
  2. The seat of this kingdom is not on earth but in heaven; there He reigneth, from there He exerteth His power and might, not that He is not everywhere according to His divine nature, but that He doth not everywhere display His glory as in heaven, in which there is no place for sin or death (which obscure Christ’s glory on earth).
  3. It is called the heavenly kingdom because its subjects, although according to the condition of nature they are earthly and animal, yet after they are co-opted into this kingdom, they become heavenly and spiritual. For as the King is, so are His subjects. Therefore, although the faithful live on earth, their conversation is in heaven. The parts of the governance of this kingdom are two: one is in the preservation and defense of the subjects, the other in not only restraining the attack of enemies but also in destroying and severely punishing enemies. He doth both in a heavenly and invisible manner. For He breatheth upon and governeth the hearts of His own by His Holy Spirit, armeth them with patience, and equippeth them with those skills which make them, though they are simple as doves, yet wise as serpents. But He breaketh the attempts of enemies by a certain hidden power, by colliding enemies with each other, and sometimes while the Church sleepeth, and sometimes by inspiring His own with such strength that (when it can be done legitimately and by calling) He useth even their work to oppress enemies for the glory of His name; but when this is not lawful, He maketh the wicked to be overcome by the patience of His own, to be wearied, He giveth them into a stupor, for He causeth the world to be overcome by their faith.

XXV. The State of Christ is Twofold: Humiliation & Exaltation. The Former Beginneth from Christ’s Conception and Endeth in His Death.

JUNIUS: We commonly call it the state of humiliation and exaltation, Luke 24:26; 1 Peter 1:11; Philippians 2:6. The state of humiliation hath two degrees: incarnation and the abasement of His person in the flesh, as the Apostle establisheth, Philippians 2:7-9. The first is when Christ, being in the form of God, emptied Himself, taking the form of a servant: and this is the greatest humiliation, which is also called emptying, Philippians 2:7. For what is more admirable than that the immense and most high God should lower Himself to become man? The second is when, having become man, He humbled Himself, subjecting Himself in all things to the Father even unto death, and this state is commonly called humiliation or submission. Between these two degrees, there is this difference: that the former is perpetual, because the human nature, which the Son of God once assumed, He retaineth forever: whence God is said to have been crucified, and God to have redeemed us with His own blood, 1 Corinthians 2:8; Acts 20:28. The latter, however, is temporary, because through ignominy He passed into glory.

AMES: The parts of Christ’s humiliation are two: life and death. The parts of life are two: the former in conception and birth, the latter after He was born. After His birth, Christ had a private life and a public life. He lived privately before publicly, because the human condition to which He subjected Himself required it, because the law of God so ordained, and because the weakness of men required that the sun of righteousness should appear to them gradually, and that they should be led from the imperfect to the perfect. The public life is that in which He openly manifested Himself to be the Messiah. In this life, there was:

  1. Initiation.
  2. Performance.
  3. Conclusion.

To the initiation pertain baptism and temptation. The performance of His public life was:

  1. In poverty and labor. The poverty of Christ was without a singular vow and without mendicity. The labor of Christ was in traveling through various regions, in watchings, and in the greatest exertion of all His powers for doing good.
  2. This public life of Christ was carried out in preaching and in performing miracles. To Christ’s preaching was always joined, as to Himself, grace and authority; as to others, the opening or hardening of the heart.

The conclusion of Christ’s life was in the preparation itself for death. The preparation for death was in the instruction and consolation of the disciples. This instruction and consolation were partly administered in the transfiguration, Luke 9:31, and in those sacraments which in a singular way pertain to the death of Christ: namely, the Passover and the Lord’s Supper; partly in example, John 13:15; partly in His last discourse, John 14-16; and partly in prayer.

The death of Christ is the ultimate act of humiliation, by which He underwent the extreme, horrible, and greatest punishments for the sins of men. It contained the greatest punishments, which equaled all the misery that the sins of men deserved. Hence the abundance of words and phrases by which this death is designated in the Scriptures. For it is not simply called death, but also cutting off, rejection, trampling, curse, accumulation of stripes. But it contained these punishments in such a way that the duration, disorder, and similar circumstances which accompany the punishments of all the damned were removed from this death, Acts 2:24. The reason is:

  1. Because such circumstances are not of the essence of the punishment itself, but adjuncts of the punishments, following and accompanying it, in those who cannot bear the punishment in such a way as to satisfy by bearing it.
  2. Because in Christ, there was both dignity and power to overcome the imposed punishment in this manner, 1 Corinthians 15:54, 57.

GOMARUS: The separation of the soul from the body is not absolute but relative. For although, by reason of the natural and immediate union, there was a disjunction of them; yet, by reason of the supernatural and mediate union in the person of the Son of God, they remained conjoined and indivisible. As the hypostatic union, which was made inseparably, required.

PROFESSOR: From what hath been said, it followeth that they do injury to God as unjust, to Christ as imprudent, who dare to assert that the smallest drop of Christ’s blood, the smallest tear, the smallest groan of His breast, could have sufficed for the redemption of the human race, who by this preposterous praise of His dignity make all that Christ suffered beyond superfluous, and imply that His death was not necessary, which yet followed all those pains of body and soul, in which there was a true, not apparent, separation of the body and soul of Christ from each other, according to the natural union, according to the effects, and according to place, while the hypostatic union of the two natures remained, sustaining the body and the soul: for since in the creed we confess that the Son of God was dead and buried, which cannot be said of Him except according to His human nature: but what pertaineth to the human nature or its parts is said of the Son of God only by reason of the union, it followeth that even in death, the Word remained conjoined to the separated parts. A true burial followed the true death of Christ, according to the same one body, which was not corrupted in the sepulcher by incineration or resolution into its elements, which Damascene calleth dialusis or aphanismós, Orthodox Faith, book 3, chapter 27, although by the separation of the living form it ceased to be a living body, Psalm 16:10; Acts 2:31; 13:35.

To the humiliation also pertaineth what is added in the creed, that Christ descended into hell, which article, although it was not formerly read in the symbols of the Roman Church or of the Eastern Church, and was omitted by some of the most ancient Fathers when they either collected the sum of Christian faith or expounded the Apostles’ Creed, nor can it be certainly determined when it was inserted into the creed: yet it is not without value if its interpretation is examined according to the analogy of faith. The name sheol, to which correspondeth the Greek hades and the Latin infernus, hath two significations, one proper, the other figurative: in its proper signification in Scripture, it is taken for all that lieth below the surface of the earth, with the notation of consuming and excepting all that were previously alive, and thus, since it regardeth destruction as far as its nature is concerned, it came to be that the state of all men departing from this mortal life is often indicated in the sacred letters by the name of hell. Metaphorically, it is taken for extreme pains and angusties, such as the damned feel. Hence, some have posited a real descent of Christ into hell; others, that it is said figuratively. Those who posit a real descent, in respect of place, for various reasons, whether true or imaginary, of places, also think variously. Some, referring to the body, understand nothing else than either the burial or the stay of Christ’s body in the sepulcher; others refer it to the soul, and that variously. For some wish that the soul descended to the places of the damned, that by His presence He might increase their punishment, and from that descent begin His triumph: others, to a place which they have fabricated in hell, in which they wish that the souls of the patriarchs were detained before Christ’s death, to which they have given the name of limbo; others, that He descended indeed to the place of the damned and to the limbo of the patriarchs, as they call it, but not by the real presence of His soul, but only by the efficacy of His divinity. Both opinions are refuted by Christ’s saying, “Today shalt thou be with me in paradise,” Luke 23:43. For unless they place paradise in hell, which is horrible to say, their limbo is necessarily torn asunder, especially with Maldonatus on Matthew 17:44 stating that Christ spoke of paradise, where He was not then; lest they understand it of Christ as God, or of the state of blessedness. The opinion of Durandus concerning the descent by efficacy, the Papists themselves refute, and if it is understood of limbo, insofar as it positeth an effect in a thing that is nowhere, it is also ridiculous with the former. Nor is there any mention in Scripture of a descent by efficacy into hell, since this descent pertaineth to humiliation and abjection; and it is attributed to the person, not to efficacy. There remain other interpretations of the article which contain truth in the matter and are beyond controversy among all orthodox, if we consider the doctrine in itself, not so if we treat of the proper sense of the article, for some think one more apt than another, which is not a matter of great importance, since all agree in the substance, and it hath already been indicated that this article was not formerly in the creed among all churches. Therefore, some wish that by this article is contained a summary of all that hath been said concerning that external humiliation of Christ, by which what was previously set forth in parts is, as it were, contracted into a narrow space at the end, to signify the whole state of humiliation, from the first to the lowest degree. Which same interpretation is embraced by those who take hell for death, and descent into hell for descent to death. Others understand by hell the state of death, and by the article of descent, that by which Christ underwent the state of death, who therefore note that Scripture never asserteth that Christ rose from the grave, but from the dead, to signify that He who was previously among the dead, in the state of the dead, did not remain so always, but at some point ceased to be dead. Not far from their sense are those who refer the article to that three-day stay, which they assert is different from burial, and that it conferred a separate benefit, and therefore deserved a separate article in the creed, in which Christ tasted the ignominy of our bodies, which Paul calleth sowing, 1 Corinthians 15:43. Unless this distinction is made, that the state of the dead is referred to the body and the soul, insofar as it is separated from the body, but the stay in the sepulcher to the body only. These latter senses, if the consequence of the articles and the order of events as narrated in the Gospel history are considered, have the greatest probability, especially since among the primary and proper significations of this phrase is that of the state of death, as was said at the beginning. Yet the interpretation commonly received in public catechisms is not less true or apt, by which by descent into hell are understood the pains of hell, and the gravity of God’s wrath and, as it were, desertion, which Christ experienced in His soul. Nor is it inconvenient to join these two descents, as some do: since both pertain to the extreme humiliation of Christ, and each hath a foundation in the phrase; and the doctrine of both is true and necessary, as is abundantly clear from what hath been said.

XXVI. The State of Christ’s Exaltation Beginneth from His Resurrection, and Besides It, Includeth His Ascension and His Session at the Right Hand.

AMES: The exaltation of Christ is that by which He gloriously triumphed over His and our enemies, Luke 24:26, “Ought not Christ to have suffered these things, and to enter into His glory?” Ephesians 4:8, “When He ascended up on high, He led captivity captive.” Colossians 2:15, “And having spoiled principalities and powers, He made a shew of them openly, triumphing over them in it.” The perfection and manifestation of this victory is in His exaltation. Therefore, although the virtual and meritorious triumph was in His death and on the cross, on which Christ is said to be exalted or lifted up, John 3:14, not only in situation and place but also in virtue and merit: yet the actual triumph, as to state, was not in humiliation but in exaltation. On the cross, Christ triumphed as on the field of victory: but in exaltation, as on the royal throne and triumphal chariot. The glory of this triumph was the change of the humble form of a servant and that most abject condition which He had undergone in it, into a heavenly blessedness, Philippians 2:9. As to His divine nature, it was only an active manifestation: as to His human nature, it was a real reception, with actions congruent flowing from it. And as the soul of Christ, now exalted, still retained the nature of a soul, so also the glorified body did not lay aside the essence of a body and its essential properties: therefore, it is neither everywhere, nor simultaneously in many places, nor can it be in the same place with another body penetratively. Which indeed all who have eyes to see can clearly perceive in those phrases of Scripture: “He was parted from them, and carried up into heaven,” Luke 24:51. The degrees of exaltation were three, opposed to as many degrees of extreme humiliation: namely, resurrection from the dead, opposed to death; ascension into heaven, to descent into the grave and to hell; and sitting at the right hand of God, to remaining in the grave and in the state of death, or among the dead.

The resurrection hath two parts: the first is the internal act, namely, revivification, by the reintegration of the union of body and soul; the second is the external act, namely, the exit from the sepulcher, for the manifestation of restored life. To this resurrection, testimonies were given:

  1. By angels.
  2. By Christ Himself, with various appearances (of which at least ten are enumerated in the Scriptures) and proofs also taken from Scripture.
  3. By men, who by seeing, hearing, and touching were made more certain of the matter.

But Christ rose not by another’s power or precariously, although this operation is attributed to God the Father, Acts 2:24, but by His own, John 2:19; 10:18. The time of the resurrection was the third day from His death and burial, Matthew 16:21; Luke 24:7; Acts 10:40; 1 Corinthians 15:4. The ends of the resurrection were:

  1. That He might be declared to be the Son of God, Romans 1:4.
  2. That He might seal the full victory over death, 1 Corinthians 15:57.
  3. That He might fulfill the parts of His office which followed death, Romans 4:25.
  4. That He might show Himself both justified and justifying others, 1 Corinthians 15:17.
  5. That He might be the substance, exemplar, and initiation of our resurrection, both spiritual and corporal, 1 Corinthians 15:20-22. For Christ, as God, is the absolutely principal cause of our resurrection: as satisfying by His humiliation and death, He is the meritorious cause of it, but as rising from death, He is the exemplary cause, and at the same time both the demonstration and the initiation.

The ascension of Christ into heaven is the middle degree or a certain progress of exaltation, by which, leaving the earth, He ascended into the empyrean heaven as into the throne of glory, Acts 1:11; Ephesians 4:10. This ascension was of the whole person. Yet it doth not belong to the divine nature except figuratively: insofar as it was the cause of the ascension, and was conjoined with the human nature in sublimity, also making its glory manifest in it, which it had before emptied itself of, when it descended into it through incarnation, but it belongeth most properly to the human nature, because it underwent a change from an inferior place to a superior one. The time of the ascension was the fortieth day from the resurrection, Acts 1:3; not sooner, because the weakness of the disciples required the delay of this interval, that their faith might be confirmed by various appearances, and that they might also be more fully instructed in those things which pertain to the kingdom of God, Acts 1:3; not later, lest they should seem to meditate an earthly life. The place from which He ascended was the Mount of Olives, Acts 1:12, where He also entered upon His extreme humiliation, Luke 22:39, to teach that His passion and ascension pertain to the same end. The place into which He ascended was the heaven of the blessed and the empyrean, which is not the Ubiquitarian heaven, as some imagine, so that this ascension would be a change of state only, and not of place: but it is the highest, above all other heavens, Ephesians 4:10; the seat, house, or dwelling of God, John 14:2; so that, as to local presence, Christ’s human nature is rightly and truly said not to be with us on earth, Matthew 26:11, although He Himself, as to His person and that spiritual efficacy which dependeth on His human nature, is always with His own even unto the end of the world. The ends of the ascension were:

  1. To place His now glorified human nature in the dwelling of glory.
  2. To show that He is the one who can penetrate the heavenly and most high counsels of God, John 3:13.
  3. To prepare mansions for all His own in the Father’s house, John 14:2-3.
  4. To take possession of the heavenly kingdom in the name of His own, Ephesians 2:6.
  5. To care for those things in heaven which pertain to their salvation by His intercession and power, John 16:7.
  6. That we might have the most certain argument of our ascension into heaven, 1 Corinthians 15:20; that we also might seek those things which are above, in thought, affection, and conversation, Colossians 3:1; Philippians 3:20.

The sitting at the right hand of God is the supreme degree of exaltation, by which He possesseth the highest glory of His mediation. Hence, the resurrection and ascension are as motions tending to this sitting: for the resurrection and ascension are in some way common to us with Christ: but the sitting at the right hand of the Father belongeth to none other than Christ alone: the supreme glory with which Christ is endowed by this sitting is properly and formally regal, Acts 2:36. This regal glory is the fullness of power and majesty, by which He governeth all things for the good of His own, 1 Corinthians 15:25.

GOMARUS: The glorification or exaltation in respect of His kingly office is the glorious introduction of Christ into the possession of His kingdom. Therefore, what is called by the Psalmist sitting at the right hand, Psalm 110:1, is expounded by the same as ruling, verse 2, and by Paul as reigning, 1 Corinthians 15:25, by synecdoche; and to it is opposed ministering, Hebrews 1:13-14. In which way also Peter explaineth this placement at the right hand with these words: “God hath made that same Jesus, whom ye have crucified, both Lord and Christ,” Acts 2:34-36. Which indeed is not to be understood of the beginning of His being made, Luke 2:11, but of the highest degree and glorious perfection of it, Ephesians 1:20-21; Philippians 2:9. Although the Greek theologians, Athanasius in his third oration against the Arians, Oecumenius on Acts 2, interpret it metaphorically as a revelation: as the word “making” is sometimes used, John 5:18; 10:33; 19:7. The Latin theologians also explained it in the former way (more happily, indeed, than most of the Greeks). For Tertullian interpreteth Christ’s sitting as presiding, On the Flesh of Christ, chapter 10. Jerome saith, “The very word ‘sitting’ signifieth the power of the kingdom,” Commentary on Ephesians 1. Sedulius: “He sitteth at the right hand of the Father, and governeth the world,” Carmen, book 5, at the end. Finally, Augustine: “Understand by the right hand the power which that man, assumed by God, received: that He who first came to be judged might come to judge,” Works, volume 9, book 2, On the Creed, chapter 7. But this glorious kingdom of Christ is either universal or particular: the universal is that by which He is constituted Lord and Judge of all creatures, Ephesians 1:20-22; Philippians 2:9-11; Acts 2:36; 17:31; Revelation 1:8; 2:23. Of which accepted kingdom, the parts and the manner are to be distinctly observed: lest we fall into many difficulties with which not a few ancient and recent writers have been entangled. For the parts of this universal kingdom entrusted to Christ are two: the first is His governance, that He may rule over all creatures and command them with supreme power, Psalm 110:2-4; Matthew 28:18; 1 Peter 3:22. The second is the submission of all creatures, commanded, Philippians 2:10-11; Hebrews 1:6; 1 Corinthians 15:24, and certainly to be fulfilled at last, Psalm 110:2; 1 Corinthians 15:27. In which way, by right and beginning, all things are said to be subject to His feet, Ephesians 1:22; 1 Corinthians 15:27, although, in the perfection of the thing, we do not yet see all things subject to Him, Hebrews 2:8. But the manner of the addition of this kingdom, according to the diverse nature of the two disparate natures in the person of Christ, is diverse. For the first manner of this kingdom, fitting to His divine nature, is the revelation and approval of that power which the Son of God, made man, holdeth over all creatures as their omnipotent creator, by His own right, forever. For as the glory of His kingdom, for the time of humiliation, emptied itself in a way, not by any privation of His dominion, but by its veiling under humble flesh and a servile and afflicted form, Philippians 2:7; so, conversely, He is said to have received the kingdom after the glorification of His flesh: not by the accession of new power which He lacked before, but by the revelation and illustrious confirmation of His former kingdom, which He had perpetually, that He might be acknowledged by all as Lord, though clothed with flesh, Psalm 110:1-2; Philippians 2:9-11. But the other manner of the universal kingdom pertaineth to the human nature, and is all finite power, far above all, and attributed to all creatures, Matthew 28:18. And this is concerning the universal kingdom of Christ. But the particular is the supreme and glorious power of building and preserving the Church, collected from all nations, Luke 19:12, 15; Psalm 2:8, which is twofold: for one is exercised in this life, the other after this life. For the former power pertaineth partly to the calling and constitution of the Church from all nations, Matthew 28:19; Acts 1:8; 13:47; Isaiah 49:6 (which before, by God’s decree and prescription, was unlawful), Ephesians 2:20; 4:10-12; partly it is referred to the saving defense against its enemies. But the latter consisteth in the glorification of the Church (which includeth the perfect subjugation of all adversaries, 1 Corinthians 15:24-26; Luke 19:27; 2 Thessalonians 1:8-9, and the donation of eternal life, Ephesians 5:27; 2 Thessalonians 1:10). Which power of Christ, according to the diversity of His natures, is assigned diverse functions. For some are proper to His divine and infinite nature, such as the sending of the Holy Spirit, John 15:26; Acts 2:17, 33; the gift of wisdom, Luke 21:15; 1 Corinthians 12:5-6, 11; the searching of hearts, Revelation 2:23; 1 Kings 8:39; the quickening and glorifying of the dead, Philippians 3:21; Romans 4:17; 8:11; and other miracles, Mark 16:20, and works proper to the omnipotence and omniscience of God. But others also belong to His human nature: such as the reproof of Paul from heaven, Acts 9:4, and His consolation, Acts 18:9, and the sending of an angel to Peter to deliver him from prison, Acts 12:7, and other similar things, consonant with the powers of a creature. Which, in explaining this power of Christ, must be prudently distinguished, not rashly confounded.

PROFESSOR: But this metaphor is taken from the custom of kings and princes, who, sitting on their throne or presiding in judgment, are wont to place at their right hand those whom they honor above all others or make sharers in their kingdom. As is customary in all principalities. Thus, King Solomon, sitting on his throne, placed his mother at his right hand, 1 Kings 2:19. So in Psalm 45:9, “Upon thy right hand did stand the queen.” So the mother of Zebedee’s children, Matthew 20:21, asked of Christ that one might sit on His right hand, and the other on His left, in His kingdom. Therefore, this sitting of Christ at the right hand of the Father signifieth not properly that natural glory and kingdom which the Son of God hath in common with the Father from eternity, for in that way, the Holy Spirit would also sit at the right hand of God: but the economic and voluntary kingdom, in which, as the God-man and our Mediator, He is appointed by the Father for the collection and defense of His Church. Whence the Apostle Paul asserteth that all things are subjected to Him by the Father, excepting Him who subjected all things to Him, 1 Corinthians 15:27.
